speakers.copy: I am a Game Dev with 10+ experience in the New Zealand Games Industry. I have a big-picture, intuitive, and playful approach to work and life. I specialise in Concept Art & Art Direction, with more recent skills in UI & UX. I am also a passionate illustrator!

Alayna Cole is a game studies lecturer, consultant, and writer. She was previously the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Manager at Sledgehammer Games (an Activision / Microsoft studio), where she ran initiatives supporting authentic game content in the Call of Duty franchise and inclusive employee experience for ~600 employees.

Alayna has experience as both a AAA and indie games producer, was the founding director of a not-for-profit, and has worked as an educator, games journalist, and published author. She holds a doctorate in creative arts; has written several books, book chapters, and journal articles on a range of subjects; and has spoken at conferences and events globally.

I’m a Unreal Engine software engineer with a passion for creating immersive, engaging gameplay experiences and developing robust systems that empower both designers and developers.

After graduating from Media Design School, I spent two years at Buildmedia (now The Boundary) before joining Mighty Eyes as a gameplay and systems engineer, eventually stepping into a lead role developing Wanderer: The Fragments of Fate - a VR time-travel adventure puzzle game. I’ve since returned to The Boundary, where I’m currently engineering a new product using Unreal Engine.

Additionally, I’ve worked on an independent project with my university team called ""Mythos Party"", an online mythological brawler, where I was responsible for engineering a significant portion of the game.

Alysha is the Variable Media Archivist for the Powerhouse, Sydney, where her work involves the documentation, preservation, digitisation and long-term storage of time-based media objects. Alysha is also a PhD researcher at Deakin University, her research explores the relationship between Museums, video games and the gaming community.

She has written papers and spoken at numerous conferences on the issues surrounding digital preservation and object obsolescence.

Andrew got his start 16 years ago making serious games in Unity, before switching to Unreal Engine 4 in 2013. Since then he has become an expert in the field in Australia, regularly speaking at UnrealFest and beyond. He balances his time between contract development on interactive projection spaces and work on his own open world UE game.

Andy Santos is a game designer and creative director with nearly 30 years of professional experience across AAA studios, startups, and indie development. He was the co-creator of EA’s SKATE franchise, credited on the first two titles that redefined skateboarding in games. At Ubisoft, he was a design lead on Driver: San Francisco, and later became Game Director at Firesprite, where he led the creative development of Horizon: Call of the Mountain for PSVR.

Andy has delivered successful games across PC, console, mobile, and VR platforms. He also spent three years working as an indie on a bunch of projects before relocating to New Zealand, where he now works with Blind Squirrel Games on new IP development. He was previously a founding team member at PortalOne, Inc., a Silicon Valley–backed hybrid games-tech startup.

Anna and Sam Barham founded Balancing Monkey Games in 2017, and Anna picked up the role of Managing Director in September 2020. Prior to this she managed a medical centre for five years, gained an MSc in Psychology, and has worked in fundraising, volunteer coordination, and tutoring disabled adults.

Antonio began his passion for video game development as a teenager on the Commodore 64. In 1997, he published his first game, FightNJokes, for MS-DOS.

He later moved to Australia in 2005 to work for N3V Games and KromeStudios, where he contributed to the development of well-known games such as Star Wars: The Clone Wars, Guardians of GA ‘Hole, and Transformers 2. During his career, Antonio was also involved in the reverse engineering of original arcade CPUs and video game boards for a project called ""Game Room"", which was published by Microsoft on Xbox Live.

After this project, Antonio joined Avalanche Studios in Sweden in 2010, where he worked on their open-world engine used in games like the "Just Cause" series.

Antonio later relocated to New Zealand to work with Gameloft on a series of mobile games, including My Little Pony, Littlest Pet Shop, and Country Friends and worked on a core engine which is still used today by some Gameloft studios, named “Casual Core”.

Throughout his career, Antonio has contributed to the development of various games across different platforms and genres, showcasing his passion and dedication for the gaming industry."

Aryuna Banzarova is Deputy Executive Director at Mytona Group, where she leads long-term growth strategies, implements internal control systems, and supports sustainable international development. With experience in administration, law and strategy, she excels at solving complex challenges, building processes, and coordinating cross-functional teams.

After moving to Singapore in 2021 to grow professionally in a global environment, Aryuna relocated to New Zealand in 2023, where she continues to contribute to Mytona’s international and regional development.

A committed professional and a mother, Aryuna balances work with raising her daughter — a combination that inspires her people-focused, sustainable approach to management. Outside of work, she enjoys sports as a way to recharge and stay grounded.

Aya is an insurance broker with Partridge Advisory. She helps tech firms of all shape and size understand their risk and secure the right insurance for their age and stage.

In 2023 Aya and Ed Barker dived headfirst into the games industry to help secure better coverage and pricing for Code grant recipients. She is doing her masters in computer science and loves to play games in her spare time.

Bart Klepka is the Creative Video & Audio Lead at Outerdawn Ltd based in Auckland NZ. With a game industry career spanning two decades, he has a passion for marrying audio to creative visuals and interactive systems.

Having covered multiple disciplines within game audio development, Bart enjoys sharing knowledge and retrospectives.

Hey! I’m Brad. I began my career in video production, editing shows like The Block NZ and First Dates, before transitioning into the world of interactive media.

Over six years at the indie studio Conical, I worked across VR, AR, film, and games wearing many hats and gaining a deep appreciation for multidisciplinary collaboration.

For the past two years, I’ve been a Producer at the New Zealand branch of Blind Squirrel Games, working alongside an incredibly talented team on both internal and external projects.

I’ve been closely involved in our internal pitching process, helping shape and refine the decks we’ve taken to publishers—and I’m excited to share some of those insights with the local dev community.

Carl de Visser is a board and video game designer. He has worked on the Endeavor board games, Path of Exile, Fortnite Creative and is currently working on original IP at Digital Confectioners.

He lives in the tiny town of Cheviot, North Canterbury with his family, 2 dogs, 2 cats and 14 chickens.

Carol is a producer, Māori game developer, and digital cultural adviser with over four years of experience in the game industry. Holding a Bachelor of Creative Technologies, Carol specializes in fostering cultural authenticity while driving creative innovation.

She is dedicated to crafting culturally rich, immersive experiences, ensuring culture is represented authentically in the digital realm, with a special focus with the integration of Te Ao Māori.

Chantelle Cole is a dedicated leader, championing growth and diversity in the games industry. As Programme Director for the NZ government’s Game Development Sector Rebate at NZ On Air, she brings a wealth of experience and a love for fostering innovation, inclusivity, and international collaboration in game development.

Previously, as CEO of the award-winning indie studio Dinosaur Polo Club, Chantelle guided the studio to international acclaim, cultivating a culture that championed diversity, pay equity, and a sense of fun. Recognised by Apple as a leader for women in games on International Women’s Day and as a finalist for ‘Inspiring Women Leader’ at the NZ International Business Awards, she has been commended for her advocacy and leadership across the industry.

With a commitment to creating supportive, equitable pathways, Chantelle is dedicated to driving sustainable growth and nurturing a thriving development community. Known for her dynamic style, she continues to apply her people-first mindset and business acumen to elevate the sector and open new doors for the next generation of creators. When not immersed in the world of games, you'll find her dabbling in everything from pottery to white water rafting, all while wrangling her two oversized, Flemish Giant rabbits.

Charlie is a queer trans UI engineer currently working for Sledgehammer Games in Australia. They are an AuDHD bean with a keen interest in code, cats and coffee. They'll happily talk for hours about wavefunction collapse, Obsidian or their cat Guinny!

Charlotte Stroebel is the Wellness and Administrative Manager at Mytona, recently named a finalist for Best Place to Work NZ. With over 15 years of experience fostering wellness across diverse workplaces — including high-profile roles like Operations Manager at the 2010 FIFA World Cup — Charlotte brings a global perspective and deep passion for employee wellbeing.

Originally from London and now based in New Zealand, Charlotte has lived and worked in South Africa and Australia. Her career has spanned event management, community building, and wellness program design. At Mytona, she leads initiatives that support both mental and physical health, believing that small, thoughtful actions make the biggest difference.

A proud parent of two boys (and self-proclaimed expert in negotiation thanks to them), Charlotte blends humour, empathy, and strategy into everything she does. She looks forward to sharing Mytona’s wellness journey and inspiring others to build more connected, supportive workplaces.

Chellew (Xiaoyan) Wu is a driven artist dedicated to creating work that tells stories and offers new perspectives.

After completing her studies in New Zealand and the United States, she began her career in the games industry before expanding into various digital fields, including media, VR, and arch-viz. Prior to returning to games at PikPok in early 2024, she spent three years as a 3D modeller at WetaFX.

Chellew believes that while beautiful visuals matter, it’s creativity and storytelling that truly breathe life into art and make it resonate.

I am a Third Culture Kid (TCK) — I’ve never really learned to stop experiencing life. I’ve moved moderately through places, careers, and phases of life, often finding myself on the edge of an identity crisis. I try (and try is the important word here) to embody empathy, vulnerability, and authenticity in everything I do.

This journey has come full circle — from coding, to designing VR training games, being a receptionist and not knowing what I wanted to do with my life to realizing that, at my core, I have always wanted to work for and with people. Lifting others up and supporting them brings out my sense of purpose.

So here I am, “production-ing” at PikPok, trying to always putting people first, then products.

My current role is Senior Game Designer at PikPok, where I’ve been working for over 5 years now. My career has a wide range of examples of creating engaging and user-friendly experiences through thoughtful design, clear documentation, prototyping, and player empathy.

I’m passionate about understanding what motivates players and developers, and I use that insight to craft games that not only deliver on user satisfaction but also meet business goals.

Claire returned home to Aotearoa to take on a Senior Manager role with New Zealand Symphony Orchestra Te Tira Pūoro o Aotearoa in 2019, after almost a decade working in the orchestra, festival and music sectors in the United Kingdom.

Recently back in London, Claire is continuing to advocate and promote NZSO’s incredible work - specifically in the recording sphere - and is collaborating with clients all over the world to make ambitions a reality.

Colin is a narrative and strategy specialist who is the creator of the horror worlds Project Tempest and Tiny Haunted Bookshop. Nominated for the Australasian Shadows and International Shirley Jackson awards, Colin is (probably) the only person to write dialogue for car-driving zombies and a sitting Prime Minister in the same year. His working background spans startups, governance, creative development, disaster recovery, and crisis management.

David Thompson is a game designer, producer, and educator with over 20 years of experience across modding, indie, AAA, and platform development. He has shipped eight titles across mobile, console, and VR, with roles at Gameloft, PikPok, Wooga, and Immutable. Most recently, David served as Product Owner at mod.io, leading UGC integrations for games like Baldur’s Gate 3, Homeworld 3, and Dying Light 2.

David is also the Game Director of Tiberian Sun Rising, a long-running total conversion mod for Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars, developed under EA’s modding guidelines. His career bridges community-driven development and professional production, with a focus on UGC systems, modding, creative empowerment, and helping studios unlock the potential of player-driven content.

He is passionate about supporting sustainable, inclusive communities within game development and empowering creators of all kinds.

"Adventurer, video game developer and flag-waving New Zealander Dean Hall created the wildly successful mod and game DayZ, which won two Golden Joystick Awards and became one of the best selling PC games of 2014.

Dean returned to New Zealand in 2015 to found his own studio RocketWerkz, based on the Auckland waterfront. Dean continued his passion for the survival genre, with sci-fi survival game Icarus reaching #1 worldwide on Steam when it launched in December 2021 and sandbox game Stationeers receiving overwhelmingly positive reviews in Early Access.

RocketWerkz has developed its own high-performance game development framework, BRUTAL, which it is using to develop Kitten Space Agency and several other in-development games.

A former Royal NZ Air Force and NZ Army officer, Dean is an accomplished mountaineer having summited Mount Everest in 2013 and skied to the South Pole in January 2020.

Ed Davis: Indie video / performance artist since the 90s - VR film/game Dev since 2018 - recently using game engines and motion-simulators in sync with FPV drone shots and CG / 3DGS tech to create natural / virtual experiences / environments for psych research and immersive gaming

Ed is a partner at Hudson Gavin Martin, New Zealand’s leading technology law firm. Ed’s main areas of practice are technology and IP development, commercialisation, protection and procurement. Ed has worked with businesses across various industry sectors (both customers and vendors), including indie game studios, and global gaming, social media and entertainment businesses.

Passionate about giving back to the industry, Ed holds and has held board positions for the NZ Software Association, NZ Game Developers Association, and ADLS Technology Law Committee. Ed is also a judge for the NZ Hi-Tech awards.

Emma brings over 20 yrs of experience in expertise in research and data-driven strategy. She established the Market Research department at PikPok and now works with an excellent team of mixed-method researchers. Emma is all about using evidence to 'build the right thing' and use testing to 'build the thing right'.

Co-founder and Lead Designer of Rare Parrot Games, makers of KGS 1st place winner 'Warrior Chef'. Multiple grant recipient from various NZ organisations; I've travelled to GDC, Gamescom, PAX AUS and GCAP to showcase our game and negotiate with publishers on behalf of the studio.

The past 4 years of experiences and research have honed my game design intuition and industry knowledge, and I'm hoping to share a useful perspective in my talk.

Hayden Simpson is a Studio Director and Senior Unreal Engineer at Prismatic Studios. He has been working as a Software Engineer for the past 10 years, spanning desktop applications development, full-stack web development, and most recently, games development, specialising in Unreal Engine.

Hayden’s responsibilities at Prismatic Studios span operations, leading technical teams, as well as hands-on development of products. His broad background sees him often providing key direction of UI/UX, as well as ensuring consistently high code quality and maintainability.

In a production capacity, Hayden has managed many projects within Prismatic, ensuring they are delivered on time, under budget, and exceeding client expectations. He has spoken around the world at conferences, delivering technical insights in game development.

Iain Sutherland is a Fair Trading investigator with a focus on online sales practices and digital design. Iain specialises in identifying misleading sales tactics used by global businesses online.

With four years in compliance and investigation roles at the Commerce Commission, and a personal passion for gaming, Iain brings important insight from his work into the way consumer law principles apply to digital game design.

Ian has more than two decades of experience working as a programmer specializing in technical design and technical art. He has worked with a number of New Zealand based studios like Cloudfire Studios, Little Lost Fox, Dinosaur Polo Club, Synty Studios and has even helped build and launch games for big international brands like Jaguar and Wimbledon.

Having finished my Bachelors of Screen Arts with Honors Majoring game development at the end of last year I jumped into my first industry job in Feb of this year. Geared with honours research about game feel and player interactions I have been the sole game designer and programmer on a 3 person team creating Note Worthy, a music education game designed to bridge the gap between music theory and entertaining narrative lead games.

Over the last 4 years I have heavily engaged with the Wellington games community, going to every networking event I could get my hands on, running Massey very own game developers club and talking as many industry peeps as I can find to gather as much insight as I can about finding entries into this wonderful industry.

I am now very excited to share all of the knowledge I have collated with those just a few step behind me in their career journeys.

James Dean is a composer, sound designer, musician, and all-around audio geek. With over eight years of experience in audio post-production and more than twenty years of playing and writing music, he couldn’t resist the adventure of diving into interactive audio. James has worked on games ranging from low-spec mobile titles to high-end VR, tackling a wide range of technical challenges without ever compromising audio quality.

In 2019, he founded Ākau Audio and has been helping developers make their games sound great ever since. James loves taking on new challenges and genuinely enjoys using technology to discover creative ways of telling compelling stories through sound.

After studying 3D and graphic designs, I started making games with some friends in South Africa in 2007. I moved to Auckland to work as a Lead Game Designer on Wonder Zoo at Gameloft, before doing the same on Monster Blade at Nubee in Singapore, and then moved to Germany to be the Product Lead on Monster World for Wooga. Missing New Zealand, I came to PikPok as a Product Manager, and worked on a range of games from Adventure Express, to Into the Dead (One and Two), Shadow Wars, Rival Stars Horse Racing, and many more. I became the first Production Manager, over seeing other Product Owners, and led the way in exploring many new development tools.

During this time I became an Enterprise Agile Coach, a Master Transformative Coach, served as President of the New Zealand branch of the International Coaching Federation, I authored a Leadership Development Framework called the  Mind Forge Leadership Behaviour and Team Development Journey by Situational Clarity, and published Positive Epic Fantasy Fiction. (As someone with ADHD, I like to keep busy)

Most of this journey was powered by a love for games and stories, a recognition that I wasn't great at things I valued, like leadership, and a desire to get better at those things, then investing all my focus into improving them.

Jason studied film producing at UNC School of the Arts and crewed on several feature films while attending college. After graduation, he moved out to Los Angeles to continue working in the entertainment industry. Over the course of 14 years, he worked in physical production, post production, visual effects, and writing. While trying to find work between shows, a friend of his asked him to work as a capture tech at Buddha Jones. He’s been there for 6 years and now leads their game capture department.

Jeff is a tech lead who bridges the gap between innovation and storytelling. Building immersive digital experiences, he combines technical expertise with a strong creative vision to craft solutions that engage users and push boundaries.

Jeff thrives on complex challenges, transforming ambitious concepts into reality through thoughtful leadership and hands-on development. His cross-platform expertise allows him to create seamless experiences that leverage the unique strengths of each technology.

Known for spotting technological opportunities and solving problems creatively, Jeff brings both analytical thinking and artistic sensibility to every project. He values knowledge sharing and takes pride in mentoring team members, helping them grow while tackling new concepts.

In fast-paced environments, Jeff's blend of technical skill, leadership ability, and creative insight makes him an ideal collaborator for projects that demand both innovation and practical execution.

Jevon Wright (she/her) is a studio founder, software engineer, community volunteer, musician, and aspiring game designer based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Aotearoa. She has been making video games in her spare time since she was 12, and is the solo developer behind the upcoming base-building/simulation game Adaptory.

Jevon holds a PhD in Computer Science and has worked professionally in New Zealand’s web and software industry for over two decades as a software engineer, front-end lead, team lead, and most recently as a Solutions Architect.

I'm a specialist in intellectual property and commercial law, with a keen interest and background in gaming and other entertainment work.

I work with several early stage gaming studios, as well as acting for several of the largest businesses in the global gaming industry.

Jon has been making games since they were sold on cassette tape, and is horrified that many people attending his talks need to look on Wikipedia to find out what a cassette tape is.

In 2019 he founded GameConsulting.com.au where he works with many screen agencies, investors, developers and publishers helping to bring indie games to market.

Dr. Jon Manning is the co-founder of Yarn Spinner and of Secret Lab, a pair of independent game development studios that build Yarn Spinner, the narrative tool that powers games like Night in the Woods, Dredge, Venba, and A Short Hike.

Jon is also the co-author of a number of books on Unity, Swift, and machine learning, and holds a PhD about jerks on the internet.

I'm the founder of Hyporeal, a Dunedin games studio who recently launched our debut; an action RPG entitled "Blackheart".

I have previously worked as a programmer at Runaway Play, a designer/programmer at Nutri-Blocks, and more recently as a designer/programmer at Spellcaster.

I am a natural communicator and multi-disciplinary creative who boasts not only strong programming skills, but a track record of leading teams and shipping quality games that resonate with players.

Julian is a new arrival to New Zealand, coming by way of Sanrio Digital, Gameloft, Fifth Journey, Uken Games, Socialpoint and SYBO Games. You may be familiar with titles he's worked on such as Hello Kitty Online, Bingo Pop, Armory & Machine, or most recently, Subway Surfers City.

He originally hails from Hong Kong, and has bounced around the world enough times to end up as far south as one can get without ending up in the Antarctic (or Dunedin!) He landed in Christchurch only this last May, where he's taking some time to try working on small projects for PC and Steam - something he knows absolutely nothing about. Good luck to him; he'll need it!

Karah Sutton is the Chief Publishing Officer at PikPok and the author of two books with Penguin Random House. With more than a decade of experience in games and entertainment, Karah oversees the Publishing operations at PikPok including marketing, advertising, customer support, community management, licensing, and public relations.

She has had the pleasure of working on more than 20 of PikPok's games since starting with the studio in 2013, including recent successes Into the Dead: Our Darkest Days, Rival Stars Horse Racing, Clusterduck, and mobile classics Super Monsters Ate My Condo (BAFTA nominee), Flick Kick Football, Four Letters, Robot Unicorn Attack 2, and the original Into the Dead.

I'm Kasey, a line producer at 37Degrees Studio. Over the past 9 years, I've worked in film, TV, games and location based experiences. Spending most of my time in visual effects, a bit in linear content for games and now I spend most my time supporting my creative development team, anything from concept art to full 3D enviornments.

I love the variety of projects I get to be involved with and the different industries and people who are involved. In my spare time, I am a pilot, a mum and a serial hobby-starter.

Kate Cruickshank is a Partner at MinterEllisonRuddWatts, specialising in commercial contracts with a focus on the technology, film, and energy sectors. With over 15 years of experience, she is known for her pragmatic and well-grounded legal advice.

Kia Abhari is a Visual Design Manager at Riot Games with 12+ years of experience leading creative teams across SEGA and MARVEL. He’s worked closely with multicultural teams in Japan and the U.S., and currently manages a diverse group of designers in Los Angeles.

Born in Iran and raised across Malaysia, and the U.S., Kia brings deep cultural awareness to his leadership style.

Kiran is community builder & filmmaker and is passionate about connecting people and moving them to see the world differently. His background is in storytelling being a freelancer documentary filmmaker over 10 years, making mini-documentaries for a range of people from monks to musicians, pole dancers to political movements.

Away from documentary, Kiran has opened a creative space 'MoveSpace' to support artists & creatives of all kinds to create & share more of what they love with the world. Kiran in 2023 brought both of his passions together to create Deeper Questions his card game that inspires deeper connection through storytelling.

He's excited about his new passion of game development and after a successful community building campaign leading to a successful Kickstarter, Kiran is excited to share his learnings and learn from others who've walked this path before him!

Kong a Lecturer in Psychology of Social Media at the University of Canterbury. His research uses computational methods to examine the emergence of online culture in social media and video games, and their effects on mental health and wellbeing in users.

In 2025, he was concurrently a Fulbright visiting scholar at the Game User Interaction and Intelligence (GUII) Lab at the University of California, Santa Cruz.

Laura is a Scotland-born, Aotearoa-based writer with over 15 years of professional experience writing for games, film, tv, adverts, apps, and more. She has a passion for diversity and equality, and loves creating safe and accessible spaces for people to enjoy.

She is currently the writer for Beyond These Stars with Balancing Monkey Games. Prior to that, she worked for Trailmix Games as Narrative Lead until 2024, has freelanced for companies including Space Ape (now Supercell London), Metacore and Papukaya. Her work in games, film and tv has won awards around the world.

Laura leads the analytics department at PikPok, providing our development teams and decision makers with insights derived from more than 1 billion user-generated data points daily. Inspired by a youth spent crafting custom games and communities in Warcraft 3, and over a decade of professional experience in analytics, Laura's a passionate advocate for the intersection between data and creativity.

I'm Lluc Romaní Brasó, also known as "LLUC3D." I'm a 3D artist from Barcelona, I came to New Zealand 10 years ago, here I have grown as an artist working for many great projects and companies like Gameloft, Media Design School and Foodstuff.

Luke has spent 13 years in the Wellington games industry, 11 of those as a game designer. He's shipped a wide variety of games at mainstays like PikPok and small start-ups like 2UP Games.

He is currently passionate about leadership, user research, non-violent communication, vision development, and how we work towards a games industry that shares the spoils more equitably.

Madeleine Clute, Founder and Creative Director. Maddy came to games from a software career, working for Google in New York City and Sydney across a wide range of products from Google Maps to data centres in both technical and management roles.

Always having had a strong passion for art and storytelling, she decided to try her hand at game development and hasn’t looked back. O’Saurus Studios is based in Melbourne and their debut title, Call of the Golden Valley will release in October 2025.

Mark is a leading developer in the XR industry with over 10 years VR, AR, MR & NUI development experience as well as 15 years of experience in software development. He is the director of engineering at Creature, working on "Starship Home", a mixed reality game transforming your living room into the bridge of a starship. Mark was the lead VR developer of the Quest version of "SUPERHOT VR". He is also working on the upcoming mixed reality title "Laser Dance".

Based in Canberra, Mark has extensive experience working with remote teams. In addition to him leading other teams, he is an independent XR developer and has released or worked on several critically acclaimed titles such as Gravity Lab, Nighttime Terror, Low-Fi, Technolust and Aussie Sports VR in cooperation with the Australian government. Industry veteran John Carmack called Nighttime Terror "competently done and well executed". Mark has won a DICE award for his work on "Starship Home", a Proto Award of the Virtual Reality Foundation for his game "Nighttime Terror" and was nominated for his game "Gravity Lab".

Mark is an alumni of the German National Academic Foundation. He holds a Bachelors Degree in Computing and Human Computer Interaction from the Dresden University of Applied Sciences as well as a Graduate Diploma of Computing from the Australian National University.

Megan is an experienced Release Manager at Tantalus North, with over 17 years of experience in the video games industry. Her background spans production, product management, release management and quality assurance, and she has worked for companies such as Pandemic, EA, Krome Studios, THQ, Defiant Development. As well as running indie studio, Screwtape Studios for 14 years.

Megan has lead QA teams on Hand of Fate and Hand of Fate 2, and has overseen the production, release or porting of titles such as Damsel, Unpacking, Cities: Skylines Remastered and Age of Empires 2: Definitive Edition for PlayStation 5.

Melanie Langlotz is the founder of Geo AR Games, a studio she launched in 2015 with one mission: to make games that don’t just entertain — they do something. From turning parks into digital playgrounds, to designing scavenger hunts that double as climate education, her games sit at the playful intersection of technology, storytelling, and systems change.

With a background in geospatial tech and a strong focus on ethical design, Melanie leads her team in building games for change — experiences made in collaboration with government, educators, and researchers to tackle real-world issues. Now, Geo AR Games is pushing into impact gaming, aiming to influence behaviour, culture, and even policy and legislation through immersive, community-driven design.

When she’s not wrangling XR prototypes or explaining to councils why fun is a legitimate public service, Melanie can be found tending to her ever-expanding menagerie of bugs, birds, and reptiles — many of whom are destined for pixel-perfect stardom in her next game.

Mia Ginaé Watkins is an award-winning filmmaker, writer, public speaker, and content creator. She's been in the video game industry for nine years, focusing on operations and program management–currently at Riot Games–and has been recognized as one of She Plays Games’ Top 100 Women in Gaming. Before Riot, she worked at PlayStation, growing from a video editor to a communications project manager. She has moderated and produced panels for the Game Developers Conference, DevCom Developer Conference, San Diego Comic-Con, DreamCon, LA Comic Con, and Music and Gaming Fest.

Previously, she served as the Community Development Director for the Black in Gaming Foundation, producing panels, mixers, and game jams nationally and internationally. On top of all these things, she founded the event consulting business, The Mighty Hostess, and is currently writing an epic fantasy novel.

Game design is my passion. I have been a professional game designer at CerebralFix for over 4 years now, but ever since I was a wee lad I had been creating little games - making paper prototypes before I had ever heard of the term. I love to entertain, those who know me can attest that I've a proclivity for wit and mischief (sending bad memes).

I am a proponent of the concept "games as art." Games can and ought represent more than simply entertainment, they are a unique medium for creative expression by nature of being a participatory experience. I enjoy long walks on the beach, and deep philosophical discussions on the nature of what it means to be creative.

Michelle Olson is a Los Angeles based game developer who most recently worked as a Mission Designer at new AAA studio Lightspeed LA. Previously in her career, Michelle worked as the Game Director and Studio Head on the magical photography game Beasts of Maravilla Island, with a focus on fostering strong communication culture and psychological safety.

In addition, she worked as a Game Designer at Meta, and as Lead Designer on Plasticity, a sustainability focused cinematic platformer. Michelle enjoys crafting experiences with strong values and meaningful emotional experiences, and has the most fun when she gets to help empower her teams and collaborators to make magic happen!

Michelle enjoys crafting experiences with strong values and meaningful emotional experiences, and has the most fun when she gets to help empower her teams to make magic happen!"

Miranda Verswijvelen is the narrative game lead at GeoAR, an Auckland-based studio specialising in digital experiences that positively impact the world, fostering education and empowerment with simulations and serious games. She holds a PhD from Auckland University of Technology researching the intersection of game narrative design and interactive learning experiences.

Miranda has more than 20 years experience in designing story-based elearning and serious games for corporate, non-profit and academic environments.

Hi! I'm Nat, an animator and artist who's been working in the games industry locally for the past 8+ years. I'm passionate about how we use games as a medium to tell stories, animation and motion capture, and emergent narratives.

I have previously worked at Conical, Skills VR, Mighty Eyes, and Media Design School. Currently I am animating at Space Rock Games :~)

Nick is a successful narrative designer in the indie and AAA game space. With over 8 years of experience, he’s known for Path of Exile: The Fall of Oriath, Path of Exile: War for the Atlas, OrbusVR, and as the Senior Narrative Designer for Sharkmob London.

Nidhi is a game user researcher with a PhD in cognitive psychology. With over a decade's experience in research, she entered gaming industry to apply her research skills in making games for "people" through understanding their psychology and motivations.

Nidhi now has over 3 years of experience in gaming industry and love talking about brain mysteries, and differentiating a good game from an amazing game!

Paris Jagger is a design graduate, self-proclaimed woke feminist, and unashamed data nerd with a passion for turning insights into impact. (and making the industry a better place for the next gen of women in the industry).

Paris was PikPok’s first intern and now works full-time, thriving in a space that champions agency and creativity

Paris Smith is a Game Producer at CerebralFix, a Christchurch-based studio renowned for crafting interactive experiences that fuse storytelling, education, and immersive technology.

With over two years of hands-on production experience, Paris specialises in streamlining workflows, supporting multidisciplinary teams, and translating creative vision into polished, playable games.

Her mahi is grounded in collaboration and clarity, ensuring each project progresses with purpose and cohesion. Paris’s expertise is supported by deep knowledge of the game development pipeline, 3D production, and agile project management.

Passionate about the power of games to elevate community kaupapa, causes, and storytelling, Paris has contributed to a range of “edutainment” projects. She takes pride in being a strong bridge between developers, stakeholders, and partners - keeping communication clear, timelines on track, and innovation alive."

My name is Reece Reilly and I am a video game developer interviewer who hosts a podcast called Kiwi Talkz where I speak with various game developers about their field of expertise and games they have worked on. The main objective with doing these interviews is to humanise game devs, so gamers can learn to appreciate the sacrifices they make to bring gamers joy.

I have spoken with over 100+ game devs from companies such as Valve, Nintendo, Rockstar, Bethesda and more. The guests range anywhere from composers such as Mick Gordon (composer on DOOM 2016/Eternal) to Shawn Layden (Former Chairman Of Playstation & CEO of Sony Interactive.)

Rick Stemm is Design Manager and Narrative Director at PikPok, two roles he originated. A writer, designer, transmedia artist, and speaker, Rick takes most pride in his community presence, connecting with fellow game devs, leaders, students, academics, artists, and more, helping to uplift the growing New Zealand games and creative industry. If he doesn't already know you, he would really like to.

Robert Walsh is the CEO and a co-founder of Krome Studios, established in 1999.

He has overseen the development and release of numerous game titles across various platforms, including PC, consoles (PlayStation, Xbox, Nintendo), and mobile. Krome Studios is particularly known for the Ty the Tasmanian Tiger series, a popular original IP. Beyond the Ty series, Robert has also steered Krome in its work on numerous licensed titles from major franchises like Spyro the Dragon, Star Wars, Hellboy, and Transformers.

Robert Walsh has also been recognized within the Australian game development community, having received an Outstanding Career Achievement award in the past. He has also been a speaker at numerous industry events.

His career demonstrates a long-standing commitment to the Australian game development scene, navigating the challenges of original IP creation, licensed game development, and the ever-evolving landscape of the games industry. He has been the driving force behind Krome Studios for over two decades.
I started my career as an animator/layout/previs artist on animated films and tv shows, I switched into games 5 years ago and haven't looked back!
Rohin Knight is a technical artist with 10+ years in games. He’s worked on mobile, AAA, and VR/MR titles, and loves tackling tricky problems, building great tools, and helping teams move faster.

Since joining IGEA in 2008, Ron has played an instrumental role in tackling the emerging issues surrounding interactive entertainment, and demonstrating the positive influence of computer and video games in the broader community particularly within the education and health sector.

Ron often appears in the media or fronting government to discuss the power of games to connect, empower, educate and inspire. Issues which he supports passionately include trade and export, funding, child safety, health, diversity and education.

Ron has sat on many working groups, boards and roundtables including an Advisory Committee Member on the ALRC’s Classification Review and holds a seat on the government’s Consultative Working Group on Cyber Safety.

More recently, Ron took the lead in the merger between the GDAA and IGEA in 2020, which saw the two associations coming together, ensuring that there was a single unified voice representing the video games industry in Australia.
Chris and I are tutors at SIT down in Invercargill and teach across the Screen Arts degree including animation, game design and concept art. We've participated in several jams over the years.

Sai Natarajan is a freelance composer with a special passion for making audiences fall in love with the worlds that storytellers create. Drawing from years of experience working with live symphony orchestras, he strives to create lush, memorable soundtracks that leave listeners with goosebumps. His current game projects include Adaptory and Shyftrs – two upcoming CODE-funded games from NZ developers.

Though passionate about video game music, Sai has done much outside the gaming space. Since 2022, his music has been performed by the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra on several occasions, including two separate mainline concert programs in 2024. Over the years, he has also written music for children's audiobooks, short films, commercials, and even a mini-documentary for Comvita.

In his spare time, Sai jams with his musician friends, dabbles in photography, and plays far too much Rocket League for his own good. He also weirdly enjoys referring to himself in the third person.

Sarah Daymond is a storyteller with a passion for figuring out what makes narratives click. As a Narrative Designer at PikPok, she draws on her background in research and analytics to better understand what resonates with audiences.

She loves exploring how stories take shape through a mix of design and player agency, and she's always up for a good discussion (or debate) about narrative design's role in game development.

Sarah, a Wellington native, has been programming at PikPok since 2018, and has had the pleasure of spending the last four years working on Into The Dead: Our Darkest Days, specializing in NPC behaviour. Her obsessions include (but are not limited to) Mass Effect and Buffy The Vampire Slayer.

I joined Balancing Monkey Games as a Producer in 2021. With no prior experience in the gaming industry, I had a lot to learn. Over the past four years, I've had the privilege of working on BMG’s second game, 'Beyond These Stars', which is soon to become my first ever released game.

You can usually find me coordinating roadmaps, managing tasks and team morale. While, also serving as the Social Media Manager, where I create & manage our text and visual content for our social platforms.

Shaun Garea is a lecturer of psychology based at Massey University. He is also the lab director at the ‘Gaming Research and Investigation Laboratory’ (GRAIL) where his focus is on tabletop roleplaying games (TTRPG’s) and the potential benefits playing such games may have.

Shaun’s broader research focus is on media psychology and how people interact with/and are affected by participatory media (his prior research in videogames has focused on cooperation, aggression, gambling/loot boxes, and obsessive-compulsive symptomatology).

A storyteller at heart Shaun is also an artist, filmmaker, and composer. His love of storytelling and how narratives influence us, how they help us grow and communicate is a passion; one that he hopes to explore with others who enjoy hearing scary or fantastical tales and/or love pretending to be goblins (at least) once a week.

Shaun Gear is an education and industry engagement specialist passionate about connecting young people with future-focused career pathways. With a background in education, workforce development, and digital transformation, he has worked extensively with schools, businesses, and organisations to bridge the gap between education and industry.

As a former board member of the New Zealand Game Developers Association (NZGDA), Shaun has been deeply involved in shaping initiatives that support the growth of Aotearoa’s creative tech sector. He has led projects like Get Into Games Aotearoa, helping to demystify careers in games and Esports and technology for students, educators, and whānau.

Shaun is dedicated to fostering industry partnerships that create real opportunities for the next generation of game developers in Aotearoa.

Shirley (Ess Jay) is a voice artist with an interest in technology (ask her about space weather and national security tech risks). She makes pleasant sounds you like to yell (or swear) at down the phone, and also dies on command.

Dr Simon McCallum has a PhD in AI and have been teaching Game Development for over 20 years. He has worked commercially as a game developer, co-founded multiple game companies and supported game development in both New Zealand and Norway.

Recently he has been active in the role of AI in society, writing policy for the University, Government and Royal Society. He has been using AI programming assistance for 3 years developing tools both for education and companies, including patented applications of AI in production.

Steve helps developers and publishers in SEA and ANZ get their games out of the door and to global audiences.

He held multiple roles in gaming across Production, Publishing, Product Management, and Partnerships. He worked on the product side at Unity, and handled mobile publishing at Electronics Arts back in the early app store days.

He relied heavily on external firepower (Dev, Art, QA) when he headed the game production team at a Singapore studio, and before that when he led a small-but-mighty creative outfit that built digital experiences for consumer brands.

Steve is now on the service provider side at TransPerfect Gaming, a full-service game outsourcing company that helps studios large and small with their game projects.

Tamara Buckland is on a mission to change the way we think about leadership. They founded The Wild Ones, an online community for disruptors and change-makers, to support people who want to challenge outdated systems and create real change.

Through their work, Tamara encourages leaders to step into their authenticity and lead with courage, creativity, and integrity. They also run BloomHQ, an HR consultancy that helps businesses build people-focused workplaces, and created A Quest Within, a leadership role-playing game that develops key skills through storytelling and adventure.

Tamara’s work empowers leaders to connect their values with bold action, so they can make the impact they want to see in the world.

speakers.position: Video Game Performance Director, educator/acting coach
speakers.copy:
Trine Jensen is a dynamic and value-driven voice director and acting coach for global clients in video games, animation, and film/TV. Known for transformative storytelling and fostering authentic connections with actors and directors to elicit memorable performances, she is an experienced Voice Director, Acting & Movement Coach, who directs and casts Voice Over for Games. Most recently she directed voice over on Rise of the Ronin released on PS5. In her past role as Vice President of Vault 501 she worked on Horizon Zero Dawn, The Frozen Wilds, The Sinking City and Desperados 3, among others.

She is an annual guest teacher at The Danish National School of the Performing Arts, and the National Film School of Denmark. She has taught for the SAG-AFTRA Foundation, The New World School of The Arts, and the Animations Institute in Ludwigsburg, Germany. Her workshops for actors and directors are focused on voice over and performance capture in games, which requires fast work on your feet. She is known for approaching character creation from the body.

She is passionate about guiding artistic visionaries to unlock their greatest creative potential.
Vee is CODE's resident Industry Development Swamp Witch and will be asking the questions for the fireside.

Vikram Rajan is an Indian-New Zealand SAG-E professional voice actor of 7 years. He has extensive experience providing work in Animation, Video Games, Commercials, Anime, ADR and Dubbing. He has worked with many studios and people across the world from New Zealand to the UK, USA, Canada, Japan, India, China, Poland and more!

Previous clients include but are not limited to: Epic Games, Ninja Kiwi, NetEase Games, NBA, Netflix, Prime Video and MORE!

Vikram is also the first POC New Zealand Voice Actor in Anime! and is also represented for Voice Acting in the US, UK and Canada - making his way into the big time as a young talent.

Vikram is also an experienced Casting Director for Animation, Film, ADR, Dubbing, Podcasts, Video Games - Both Union and Non-Union. Vikram runs an international casting roster with hundreds of talented voice actors across the globe!

He also has On-Screen and Stage Acting experience, with a Bachelor of Performing and Screen Arts from Unitec.

Vikram is a internationally known multi faceted talent who will invigorate all your projects with life!

I’m a commercial lawyer who helps businesses do good things. Based in Dunedin (and a regular visitor to Wellington), I love technology and game development - especially indies. I'm also chair of Startup Dunedin, helping anyone in Dunedin who wants to start or grow something new.

Outside of work and family, I'm a PC gamer and am trying to work my way through as many NZ-made games as I can.

Zach Dodson runs a small, sad studio in Wellington called Interactive Tragedy, Limited. Its debut game, Sub-Verge, was relapsed this year, along with Subtle Mind, a companion novella he wrote. He co-founded the Visual Narrative Lab at Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington where he teaches visual, design, and game students storytelling across media.

He is the author of the illuminated novel Bats of the Republic, which has interactive paper elements, and has worked on other television and screen-based projects. A random selection of experiments can be seen at zachdodson.com.

Zelle describes herself as a huge nerd, an anarchist, and a stuffed animal collector. She studied interactive technology and game development at Massey University and now works with Tūhura Tech, a charity offering Montessori-style tech workshops to young people around the Wellington region.

Outside of work, her biggest passions are ethical game design, vintage fashion, and great food.

Zsombor Pirok is the founder and managing director of Space Rock Games, a fully-remote Unreal Engine specialist co-development studio based in New Zealand.

He started the studio in the middle of the pandemic in 2020 with a group of fellow university students, and has since grown it into a team that works with major developers and publishers around the world to tackle complex Unreal Engine challenges, while also developing their own original IP.

Along the way, he’s raised over $2 million NZD in VC funding and navigated the many challenges of building a sustainable studio from the ground up. Zsombor’s passionate about sharing the lessons he’s learned — especially the things he’d do very differently next time.

Anna and Sam Barham founded Balancing Monkey Games in 2017, and Anna picked up the role of Managing Director in September 2020. Prior to this she managed a medical centre for five years, gained an MSc in Psychology, and has worked in fundraising, volunteer coordination, and tutoring disabled adults.

Sam began working on his first game Before We Leave in 2017 as a hobby project, while balancing the other demands of full-time work and fatherhood. He started his software development career 25+ years ago, working on the children’s television programme “Squirt” at Animation Research Limited and other assorted tomfoolery.

Lauren Archer is a Special Counsel at MinterEllisonRuddWatts, specialising in corporate law. She has a wealth of experience advising technology companies on their structure and helping them secure investor funding, from initial seed rounds to exit strategies.

Additionally, Lauren has extensive experience representing investors and private equity firms in these investments and exit transactions. This dual perspective gives her valuable insights into maximising and protecting the appeal and value of your project.
Developer at GeoAR games working on a variety of projects from mobile, web and AR.

I’m a commercial lawyer at Avid.legal, helping Kiwi innovators navigate their legal challenges as they grow. I’m new to the game development world, but I’ve worked closely with startups, creatives, and software companies - so I get what it’s like trying to build something great on limited time and budget.

Outside of work, I’m a long-time Sims enthusiast and a big fan of clever world-building - whether it’s in games, books, or the way creative studios craft their brand and story. That same appreciation for creativity drives my approach to legal work: I aim to make contracts feel a little less intimidating and a lot more useful.

Stephen is Chief Operating Officer at Auckland-based PC games studio RocketWerkz, managing a team of over 65 game developers.

He was also chairperson of the NZ Game Developers Association for 10 years, and has sat on various Government and industry advisory boards to help grow New Zealand's digital exports. He also has a career in tech startups, games marketing for the likes of Xbox and serious games at InGame Limited.

Mario Wynands is the CEO and co-founder of PikPok, a leading publisher of video games for mobile, desktop, and console based in Aotearoa New Zealand.

Since 1997 he has led the studio in building a successful games portfolio that includes the critically and commercially successful Rival Stars® Horse Racing, Into the Dead® and Into the Dead 2, Super Monsters Ate My Condo™, Shatter® and more, which have been recognized with BAFTA and DICE Award nominations, as well as included on App Store and Google Play best of year lists.

Mario is a graduate of Victoria University in Wellington with degrees in business management and computer science.

I am an award-winning Creative Art Director with over 30 years experience working on a wide range of projects including book publishing, collectibles and both table-top and digital games.

I have worked with world-class game designers, illustrators and artisans from around the globe on high-profile IPs such as Dungeons & Dragons, Star Wars, Lord of the Rings, The Hobbit and more.

Professor Jeff Brand is an internationally recognised and nationally awarded career academic in the discipline of communication and media with expertise in quantitative research methodology, an intellectual interest in policy for the digital economy, and leadership experience in tertiary operations and governance.

New Zealand Plays 2025 is the 8th report Professor Brand has authored, revealing the demographics of who plays games in New Zealand alongside overall attitudes towards games.

Calvin is a Senior Associate at Hudson Gavin Martin, New Zealand’s leading technology law firm. Calvin helps clients with corporate structuring, shareholder issues, capital raising and M&A.

Calvin has worked with businesses across various industry sectors (both customers and vendors), including indie game studios, and global gaming, social media and entertainment businesses.

Tobi administers the NZGDSR together with Chantelle Cole at NZ On Air. Prior to supporting the NZ Games Industry he worked at Riot Games during 6 of its early years of success and went on to advise organisations in New Zealand on culture and Agile development techniques.
Andy Burusphat is a game developer and technical artist currently working on Bento Blocks and Infernal Cleaner.

Sami is a programmer with over 7.5 years of experience making games. Having previously worked at PikPok, he is now developing roguelike deckbuilders at Big Adventure. Currently, he is been leading the technical development of Dream Team Supreme, a roguelike deckbuilder with online co-op.

Dan Milward has 20 years of experience in the games industry, with the last decade focused on the intersection of gaming and education in Aotearoa. Based in Wellington, he runs his own game studio and has advised government agencies, game studios, and creative organisations on initiatives that improve digital fluency for young people. He recently managed the HEIHEI platform for NZ On Air, helping preserve and promote locally made games and content for tamariki.

Amila Nuhodzic is a project and operations manager with a diverse experience in digital and tabletop game development, creative design, and people experience. Her skills shine in project leadership, improving processes and workflows, documentation, and building community and culture.

Penelope is a senior game designer and mentor with years of AAA experience designing and advocating for the player experience across multiple genres and platforms.

From working on ‘The Sims’ franchise at EA, to designing new gameplay based on ‘Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon’ at Ubisoft, Penelope loves drawing on her unique experience and diverse creative background to explore the possibility space and create the most exciting, yet achievable, design outcomes.

Alexander Swords is currently narrative lead on the transmedia interactive experience Totem Teller and creative lead on an unannounced game by CerebralFix. Recent work has included Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora for Ubisoft, and the Future Water mixed reality educational experience for Melbourne Water with S1T2.

They also teach interactive and immersive storytelling courses at National Institute for the Dramatic Arts (NIDA) and the Victorian College for the Arts at Melbourne University (VCA), and currently hold a position on the Australian Writers’ Guild Advisory Council. A graduate of RMIT, QUT and Griffith University, they’ve spent a career exploring the transformative power of storytelling to better lives and society.

For 28 years Jeff has been supporting Game Developers with the resources they need to launch their games. With experience ranging from hardware components to middleware and tools, and across PC, Consoles, and Mobile devices, developers from Indies to AAA as well as Publishers. Currently working at Unity to support game developers in New Zealand, Australia, North America, and Europe.

Érika Casab is a Mexican Game Artist now based in NZ, working for Saltworks Entertainment. With over 10 years of experience in creative fields such as comics, animation, film, video games; she has worked with clients in USA, Latin America, Australia and New Zealand. She is also known for her educational content for Small Robot Studio that has gathered on Youtube more than 4 million views and +75K subscribers.

Outside of work, her passions include snowboarding, horseback riding, dog training and eating spicy chips.

I've been working in the gaming space for about 4+ years - within a small studio called Mīharo - delivering both serious games on behalf of clients and our own VR title - Colorway Antics. Playful is an exciting new venture designed to support the indie scene through the challenges of publishing their title(s). We are a small core team, offering a range of services designed to provide high-value and targeted play-testing.

Ragnar Anderson has been working in sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) since 2008, at organizations in the United States, Finland, and New Zealand. Her research has primarily focused on young people's sexual health, sexuality education, contraceptive experiences, and the relationship between sexual health and wellbeing.

Ragnar earned her master’s degree in public health from Columbia University in 2011, with a focus on sexual and health and the importance of pleasure in sexual health. She is currently working on her PhD at which examines how parents and pre/teens talk to one another about sex, sexuality and relationships. She began as the Senior Research and Policy Advisor at Sexual Wellbeing in February 2024.

Emma is a forever GM, avid TTRPG nerd, and former developer who’s spent over two decades helping people make sense of messy problems. She’s the founder of Grey Matter Development, where she combines systems thinking and tabletop role-playing games to help nerdy professionals step out of black-and-white thinking and explore the “grey” instead.

Tash is a UX/UI Tech Artist with over three years of experience and a Bachelor of Creative Technologies, specializing in rapid iteration and creative problem-solving with a background in VFX and leadership roles including producer and assistant manager.

Passionate about finding innovative ways to implement striking UI effects, Tash bridges the gap between technical execution and visual storytelling to create memorable digital experiences.

Jeremy is a Senior Researcher at PikPok who brings fresh SaaS UX expertise to gaming. He blends market research with player insights to decode what makes gamers tick.

A lifelong gamer turned games researcher, he transforms data and player feedback into better gaming experiences.

Grant McIntosh is a Principal Compliance Adviser with a background in standards compliance and enforcement. Grant has worked at the Commerce Commission for ten years including stints in fair trading investigations, product safety, and compliance. The Commission’s Engagement and Compliance team undertakes monitoring to identify trends, and engages with businesses to clarify regulatory expectations.

A game developer who specializes in narrative design, implementation, and programming. Jarory inspires his colleagues and next generation developers through collaborative projects and teaching game development.

As a developer he’s worked on properties such as Madden, Marvel, and Star Wars as both a Narrative and Technical Designer. He dedicates his spare time to a Hip Hop RPG which he describes as a passion project. He has participated in multiple game jams including global game jam and train jam.

As a developer of color, he seeks to amplify minority voices through inclusive design, unique perspectives in narrative, community service, and activism. Jarory is also a community organizer for Black in Gaming (BiG) and a member of the Latinx in Gaming community as well as President of the board for Global Game Jam. His current studio, Coquito Games, is the culmination of his years of experience and passion for telling stories from under represented voices.

As a full time private music teacher, Johno uses games and gamification to deliver fun and engaging lessons. He has recently founded local game studio Low Hanging Toot, with the aim of collaborating with developers and artists to develop high-quality music education games.

Ben has a PhD in Human Factors Psychology and over two decades of research experience. He has helped ship 90+ games, plus worked on 36 seasons of Fortnite Battle Royale.

Previously he was Director of User Experience Research at Epic Games, but has recently returned home to New Zealand.

Brittney Morris is an award-winning game writer, with projects such as The Lost Legends of Redwall, Subnautica: Below Zero, Marvel's Spider-Man 2, and Marvel's Wolverine. She's also the bestselling author of SLAY, The Cost of Knowing, Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales - Wings of Fury, and The Jump.

Brittney is an NAACP Image Award nominee, an ALA Black Caucus Youth Literary Award winner, and an Ignite Award Finalist. She has an economics degree from Boston University and spends her spare time reading, playing video games, and not doing enough yoga. She lives in Philadelphia.

Nat caught the entrepreneurial bug at university and at 19, embarked on her first venture. Twenty years on, she’s had multiple exits, a fair few failures, and everything in between.

With a knack for tackling complex problems, she helped change the financial habits of nearly 200,000 customers through her last startup, Hatch. Now, she’s closing the gender leadership gap with Powrsuit, a career accelerator for women at every stage.
Tom Lewis is a Game Developer with 7 years experience in both programming and design. He is passionate about roguelike game design and programming flexible game systems for easy iteration.
Lead designer of 'A Quest Within', a TTRPG under the Leadership Treehouse umbrella with the purpose of guiding people to develop leadership skills under the premise of play as learning.

Jacob Grossman is a gameplay programmer who has worked at Weta Workshop for the last four years. For Tales of the Shire, his primary contributions were gameplay and narrative cameras, the gridless decoration system, and other gameplay systems. Prior to this he worked as a game development tutor, an artist in a number of roles in the animation industry and as a graphic designer.

With over 30 years in the games industry, including leadership positions at Electronic Arts and Activision, and 15 years helping lead Ninja Kiwi, Scott focuses that history and experience on what he sees as the core essentials of sustainable game development: inspired, healthy, and collaborative teams, creative and technical excellence fuelling innovative gameplay, and fair business practices that enable fresh, hungry teams to succeed.

Sasha is an experienced leader in the mobile gaming industry with 12+ years track record at Mytona.

Her game industry journey started in 2011 at Sulus Games, a casual video games developer in PC market, and further continued in Mytona as the business pivoted to the mobile games market in 2012. During her tenure, she was taking a variety of functions, including that of a Game Producer and a Business Development Manager.

At her current role of an Executive Director at Mytona, Sasha has been facilitating all business operations by ensuring the administrative processes run smoothly and efficiently, supporting clear communication and streamlined decision-making throughout the team. She has been coordinating key areas like corporate strategy, business administration and public relations initiatives.

Liam Esler is a multi-award-winning game developer specialising in studio management, narrative design and production. With over 16 years experience making games, in addition to his experience as a producer, designer and writer, he has a background in numerous non-traditional roles including conference management, sales, lobbying, and entrepreneurship.

This broad focus led him to co-found Summerfall Studios with David Gaider and Elie Young in 2018, where he works as Managing Director to build and support the next generation of kickass game developers.

Summerfall Studios, based in Melbourne, released its multi-award winning and Grammy/BAFTA nominated first title Stray Gods: The Roleplaying Musical in August of 2023.

Liam is currently Project Director on Malys, Summerfall’s latest game, currently in Early Access.

One of the videogame industry’s most celebrated writers, David is a game design veteran of over 25 years, having started his career in 1999 working on BioWare's Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn as a narrative designer. His later credits include Neverwinter Nights (2002), Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic (2003), and the Dragon Age series where he acted as world designer and Lead Writer.

He left BioWare in 2015 after briefly working on Anthem to become Creative Director at Beamdog, where he developed several prototypes and built a significant internal content team before departing in 2018 to co-found Summerfall Studios, where he is currently Creative Director.

As BNZ's Head of CreativeTech Business, Olivia works closely with CreativeTech businesses in New Zealand across the likes of gaming, education technologies, design, media, virtual and augmented reality, animation, film, music technologies and more.

Olivia is passionate about innovation in this sector and supports businesses with financing, expertise and industry connections.

Nick Jennings is helping bring Playful, a new initiative dedicated to transforming how indie developers playtest games.

With a background in digital production and years of experience delivering creative and technical projects, Nick now focuses on embedding structured, audience-led feedback earlier in the game development lifecycle.

Zaire is a writer and narrative designer for games. She has worked at Unknown Worlds on Subnautica: Below Zero and at Naughty Dog. She is currently a senior writer at Compulsion Games, which just released South of Midnight.
I'm at Tutor at SIT I teach in our animation and game design strands
Director of Astronaut Diaries, an indie game studio based in Auckland that specialises in story driven action games. They are currently working on their debut title, Denari.

A Fellow Chartered Accountant, Julian brings a wealth of financial acumen to the table. Julian is the founder of CFO 4 U which provides Virtual Chief Financial Officer services to startups and high-growth companies.

Julian is the recent recipient of Kotahitanga Award by Angel Association New Zealand. The Kotahitanga Award recognises those people in the angel community who have made an outstanding contribution to the industry. It acknowledges those who have selflessly given personal time and energy for a sustained period and contributed to the professionalism, profile and reputation of angel investment in New Zealand.

For almost twenty years, I have been passionate about creating unique and engaging experiences for players. I'm a T-shaped developer with experience in all facets of game development, with a focus on character and animation systems.

Chris Murphy is a Principal Technical Artist at Epic Games with game development credits on multiple platforms. Chris has over a decade of experience with Unreal Engine, 9 years at Epic, a Bachelor of Computer Science, and a Bachelor of Multimedia, culminating in a broad skillset across a range of game development disciplines.

Chris’ role in the Developer Relations team at Epic Games is to help Unreal Engine developers build successful projects with Unreal Engine support and advice.

Tamihana Greaves has worked in the New Zealand games industry for the last 15 years. He first began as a 2D Artist and Animator at Ninja Kiwi, working predominantly on the Bloons TD series. Now he works as Art Director on the yet-to-be released project Denari, at Astronaut Diaries.

Louis Lambert is QA Lead at Blind Squirrel Games, bringing a sharp technical edge and deep experience in testing complex, live games. Prior to this, he spent four years at RocketWerkz, where he led QA across multiple projects and expansions — most notably managing over 189 weekly patches for Icarus post-launch.

His work spanned performance validation, multiplayer stability, platform compliance, and player experience, establishing QA as a critical partner in the dev cycle. Louis thrives in fast-moving, iterative environments and is passionate about embedding QA earlier in development to reduce risk, improve collaboration, and ship with confidence.

Antony is CODE's Regional Content Manager, Upper North Island. He brings a plethora of tech skills and experience working across a variety of platforms, such as PlayStation, Xbox, PC, and Nintendo Switch. Testing everything from mobile to AAA. Outside of work, Antony is a dedicated artist who has self-published a number of comic books. He’s also a keen musician who plays bass guitar in multiple bands in Auckland.

Olivier brings a sharp, player-first mindset to every stage of game development. He’s currently leading Dream Team Supreme, a co-op roguelike where scientists pilot giant robots against a monster invasion.

At PikPok, he managed a 30-person team to ship Agent Intercept on time and under budget for Apple Arcade, and helped grow Rival Stars Horse Racing revenue by 66% through player-driven updates. With 300+ titles shipped in 40+ languages at Keywords, Olivier blends global insight with deep QA expertise—having built test pipelines, mentored teams, and embedded quality into the dev process from day one.

sessions.title: Extremism and Game Development
sessions.copy:
The Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet has allocated funding for me to analyse the relationship between game development and pathways to violence and extremism. In the past this research as mostly been conducted by sociologists outside of the industry.

We will unpack the analysis of game development and the hidden pathways to extremism and share as game designers, what features of games are associated with fostering isolation.

In this workshop we will have open dialogue as well as round tables to discuss tools for community managers to help find and mediate these issues, with a focus on how to identify and reintegrate players back into communities. The input from this workshop will be reviewed and a wrap-up talk given the following afternoon to present findings and share next steps.

speakers.copy:
Dr Simon McCallum has a PhD in AI and have been teaching Game Development for over 20 years. He has worked commercially as a game developer, co-founded multiple game companies and supported game development in both New Zealand and Norway.

Recently he has been active in the role of AI in society, writing policy for the University, Government and Royal Society. He has been using AI programming assistance for 3 years developing tools both for education and companies, including patented applications of AI in production.

sessions.title: Casting
sessions.subtitle: Bringing the human to your work
sessions.copy:
Join Robin Williams and SJ as they workshop best casting practices and tips they've learned along the way. Virtual guests will also be in attendance as we look to provide working professionals points of view and advice.

Attendees should bring their preferred note-taking tools such as a notebook and pen, laptop, or tablet; and any questions or work they would like casting help with.

speakers.copy: Shirley (Ess Jay) is a voice artist with an interest in technology (ask her about space weather and national security tech risks). She makes pleasant sounds you like to yell (or swear) at down the phone, and also dies on command.

sessions.title: Speed Concepting in 3D with Blender
sessions.copy:
Learn how to quickly sketch out ideas in 3D using Blender. This workshop will provide step-by-step guide, from blocking out to lighting a scene, focusing on efficient workflows for visual development and concept art.

Topics covered:

- 3D Modelling strategies to speed up workflow, our goal is to be comfortable designing things in 3D space.

- Lightning techniques to match a colour reference.

- Creating a small diorama scene featuring some New Zealand wildlife.

This is a beginner friendly workshop, but it is also aimed at seasoned artist looking to learn Blender as a tool for concepting and visual-development.

Attendees are encouraged to bring their laptops (PC, Mac or Linux) - or are welcome to just watch.

speakers.copy: Andy Burusphat is a game developer and technical artist currently working on Bento Blocks and Infernal Cleaner.

sessions.title: Multiplayer with FishNet and Unity Relay
sessions.copy:
This workshop goes through the process of setting up host-based multiplayer functionality in Unity.

Using FishNet (a networking framework) and Unity Relay (a Unity service), it will cover getting a simple multiplayer game up and running quickly and cheaply.

Attendees can follow along with laptops using a pre-made project used for the workshop; or can simply take notes if preferred.

speakers.copy: Sami is a programmer with over 7.5 years of experience making games. Having previously worked at PikPok, he is now developing roguelike deckbuilders at Big Adventure. Currently, he is been leading the technical development of Dream Team Supreme, a roguelike deckbuilder with online co-op.
Tom Lewis is a Game Developer with 7 years experience in both programming and design. He is passionate about roguelike game design and programming flexible game systems for easy iteration.

sessions.title: Designing a UGC and Modding Strategy for Your Game
sessions.copy:
This workshop provides developers with a hands-on framework for designing a practical, people-first UGC and modding strategy tailored to their game. Whether your goal is to support cosmetics, levels, scripting, or complete modding tools, you’ll learn how to assess your community, game systems, and studio capacity to determine what makes sense — technically, creatively, and strategically.

Drawing from my experience supporting UGC and mod integrations at mod.io — including games like Baldur’s Gate 3, Dying Light 2, and Homeworld 3 — I’ll guide you through scoping, technical feasibility, community needs, and the impact on retention, engagement, and product longevity.

We’ll also cover key considerations around moderation, legal frameworks (from a product perspective, not legal advice), and emerging monetisation models through platforms like mod.io and Overwolf.

By the end, you’ll leave with a draft UGC strategy tailored to your game — and a clear understanding of how creator empowerment drives sustainable, community-powered growth.

Attendees should bring their preferred note-taking tools such as a notebook and pen, laptop, or tablet.

speakers.copy:
David Thompson is a game designer, producer, and educator with over 20 years of experience across modding, indie, AAA, and platform development. He has shipped eight titles across mobile, console, and VR, with roles at Gameloft, PikPok, Wooga, and Immutable. Most recently, David served as Product Owner at mod.io, leading UGC integrations for games like Baldur’s Gate 3, Homeworld 3, and Dying Light 2.

David is also the Game Director of Tiberian Sun Rising, a long-running total conversion mod for Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars, developed under EA’s modding guidelines. His career bridges community-driven development and professional production, with a focus on UGC systems, modding, creative empowerment, and helping studios unlock the potential of player-driven content.

He is passionate about supporting sustainable, inclusive communities within game development and empowering creators of all kinds.
