sessions.title: Unlock Wellington: Playful City Jam
sessions.copy:
Dan Milward and Jimmy Baird will facilitate a fast-paced workshop / Game Jam where attendees break into teams to design playful, game-based experiences to unlock a more vibrant Wellington.

Attendees should bring their preferred note-taking tools such as a notebook and pen, laptop, or tablet.

speakers.copy: Dan Milward has 20 years of experience in the games industry, with the last decade focused on the intersection of gaming and education in Aotearoa. Based in Wellington, he runs his own game studio and has advised government agencies, game studios, and creative organisations on initiatives that improve digital fluency for young people. He recently managed the HEIHEI platform for NZ On Air, helping preserve and promote locally made games and content for tamariki.

sessions.title: ABC Design Workshop
sessions.subtitle: Unpacking the Player Experience
sessions.copy:
Design is the solution to a problem. Anyone can appreciate good design in a finished product, but when you’re deep in the weeds of game development it’s a different story. When a feature or game feels meaningless, confusing, or 'wrong', it's easy to feel frustrated and lost. So how do we move forward, figure out what the problem is, and instead create experiences that feel 'right'?

In this practical workshop aimed at game designers - or indie teams without their own - senior game designer Penelope Murphy will take attendees through methods of design thinking, dig deeper into the problem space, and unpack what the player experience is really about. By the end of the workshop, participants will learn new tools and ways to solve problems, making clear and effective design choices as easy as ABC.

Attendees should bring their preferred note-taking tools such as a notebook and pen, laptop, or tablet.

speakers.copy:
Penelope is a senior game designer and mentor with years of AAA experience designing and advocating for the player experience across multiple genres and platforms.

From working on ‘The Sims’ franchise at EA, to designing new gameplay based on ‘Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon’ at Ubisoft, Penelope loves drawing on her unique experience and diverse creative background to explore the possibility space and create the most exciting, yet achievable, design outcomes.

sessions.title: Level up your leadership
sessions.subtitle: Why RPGs are the future of leadership and team development
sessions.copy:
This workshop is all about the benefits of role playing and play, as a way to build more confident and stronger leaders and teams.

Using my own leadership RPG that I've designed, we will play with attendees giving them a first-hand experience of the benefits of role playing and how it can easily slot into our day to day work, with a bit of creativity.

I will provide stories and examples and ideas for both leadership development as well as team/culture development.

Attendees should bring their preferred note-taking tools such as a notebook and pen, laptop, or tablet.

speakers.copy:
Tamara Buckland is on a mission to change the way we think about leadership. They founded The Wild Ones, an online community for disruptors and change-makers, to support people who want to challenge outdated systems and create real change.

Through their work, Tamara encourages leaders to step into their authenticity and lead with courage, creativity, and integrity. They also run BloomHQ, an HR consultancy that helps businesses build people-focused workplaces, and created A Quest Within, a leadership role-playing game that develops key skills through storytelling and adventure.

Tamara’s work empowers leaders to connect their values with bold action, so they can make the impact they want to see in the world.

Emma is a forever GM, avid TTRPG nerd, and former developer who’s spent over two decades helping people make sense of messy problems. She’s the founder of Grey Matter Development, where she combines systems thinking and tabletop role-playing games to help nerdy professionals step out of black-and-white thinking and explore the “grey” instead.
Lead designer of 'A Quest Within', a TTRPG under the Leadership Treehouse umbrella with the purpose of guiding people to develop leadership skills under the premise of play as learning.

sessions.title: Carrier-Bag Storytelling for Games
sessions.copy:
Narrative design structures for games based on curiosity, compassion and transformation. For those who share Ursula K. Le Guin’s view that story is change, and that conflict is only one of the many and varied ways change can be achieved on the screen and in the hearts and minds of players.

It will start with simple techniques for allowing curiosity as a primary player motivation, and finish with the transcendental form as an advanced technique for human-scale stories that elevate compassion as a modular alternative to conflict that holds space for feminist, queer, and anti-colonial concepts.

Attendees should bring their preferred note-taking tools such as a notebook and pen, laptop, or tablet.

speakers.copy:
Alexander Swords is currently narrative lead on the transmedia interactive experience Totem Teller and creative lead on an unannounced game by CerebralFix. Recent work has included Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora for Ubisoft, and the Future Water mixed reality educational experience for Melbourne Water with S1T2.

They also teach interactive and immersive storytelling courses at National Institute for the Dramatic Arts (NIDA) and the Victorian College for the Arts at Melbourne University (VCA), and currently hold a position on the Australian Writers’ Guild Advisory Council. A graduate of RMIT, QUT and Griffith University, they’ve spent a career exploring the transformative power of storytelling to better lives and society.

sessions.title: Epic Games: Robots Alive!
sessions.subtitle: Procedural Rigging, Animation, and Physics in Action
sessions.copy:
Dive into setting up characters for animation and gameplay with rigging, procedural elements, physics, and animation tools in Unreal Engine.

This live demonstration will focus on effective techniques to enhance project fidelity and ease workflow difficulties.

speakers.copy: For almost twenty years, I have been passionate about creating unique and engaging experiences for players. I'm a T-shaped developer with experience in all facets of game development, with a focus on character and animation systems.

sessions.title: Bloons Card Storm
sessions.subtitle: How we Translated Hit into a Card Game
sessions.copy:
We will explore the creative challenges faced while making Ninja Kiwi's new game: Bloons Card Storm. Hear about how we translated our popular tower defense game, BTD6, into a unique card game, from the perspective of the UI/UX designer & Co-Art Lead Aimee Cairns.

I will give insight into our process for art direction, ui/ux, 3D production, and design.

This talk will be useful for those involved in Creative Direction, Art Direction, or UI/UX Design.

speakers.copy: I am a Game Dev with 10+ experience in the New Zealand Games Industry. I have a big-picture, intuitive, and playful approach to work and life. I specialise in Concept Art & Art Direction, with more recent skills in UI & UX. I am also a passionate illustrator!

sessions.title: DE&I Programs Don't Work
sessions.subtitle: (Let Me Tell You Why)
sessions.copy:
Headlines about diversity, equity, and inclusion have become fixated on the fact that DE&I programs are ineffective. I've worked as a DE&I practitioner and consultant for over a decade, and I agree—they don't work. But it depends what we're using as our measure for success.

This talk will contain the following information and actionable steps for attendees: What is DE&I? What is a DE&I program? How do we know if these programs "work"? What are the goals of DE&I programs? History of corporate DE&I; How to rebuild DE&I programs to make them effective; and Actionable steps for improvement.

speakers.copy:
Alayna Cole is a game studies lecturer, consultant, and writer. She was previously the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Manager at Sledgehammer Games (an Activision / Microsoft studio), where she ran initiatives supporting authentic game content in the Call of Duty franchise and inclusive employee experience for ~600 employees.

Alayna has experience as both a AAA and indie games producer, was the founding director of a not-for-profit, and has worked as an educator, games journalist, and published author. She holds a doctorate in creative arts; has written several books, book chapters, and journal articles on a range of subjects; and has spoken at conferences and events globally.

sessions.title: From Code to Collection:
sessions.subtitle: How Game Developers Can Shape the Future of Video Game Preservation in Museums
sessions.copy:
As video games continue to evolve as a major cultural and artistic medium, museums are increasingly seeking ways to collect, preserve, and exhibit games and consoles. However, preserving games isn’t just about keeping copies of software, it’s about maintaining playable experiences, understanding development contexts, and ensuring their cultural impact is recognised for future generations.

This talk will explore how game developers can collaborate with museums to safeguard gaming history, addressing challenges such as technological obsolescence, digital rights, and the preservation of online and evolving games. By leveraging the expertise of developers, we can create sustainable strategies to ensure video games remain accessible as a cultural record.

speakers.copy:
Alysha is the Variable Media Archivist for the Powerhouse, Sydney, where her work involves the documentation, preservation, digitisation and long-term storage of time-based media objects. Alysha is also a PhD researcher at Deakin University, her research explores the relationship between Museums, video games and the gaming community.

She has written papers and spoken at numerous conferences on the issues surrounding digital preservation and object obsolescence.

sessions.title: Game Design for Life:
sessions.subtitle: 30 Years of Tips, Lessons, and Learning
sessions.copy:
Andy Santos, Creative Director at Blind Squirrel Games and Industry Expert at Canterbury Christ Church University, takes you on a journey through three decades of game design - from the formative days at Psygnosis to shaping major franchises with EA, Capcom, Ubisoft, and PlayStation.

Along the way, he’s co-created Skate, directed a Resident Evil title, led development on a Horizon game, and explored the challenges of indie development with projects like Polterguys.

This talk pulls back the curtain on the core principles, creative discipline, best practices, and real-world lessons that turn ambitious ideas into impactful, memorable games.

speakers.copy:
Andy Santos is a game designer and creative director with nearly 30 years of professional experience across AAA studios, startups, and indie development. He was the co-creator of EA’s SKATE franchise, credited on the first two titles that redefined skateboarding in games. At Ubisoft, he was a design lead on Driver: San Francisco, and later became Game Director at Firesprite, where he led the creative development of Horizon: Call of the Mountain for PSVR.

Andy has delivered successful games across PC, console, mobile, and VR platforms. He also spent three years working as an indie on a bunch of projects before relocating to New Zealand, where he now works with Blind Squirrel Games on new IP development. He was previously a founding team member at PortalOne, Inc., a Silicon Valley–backed hybrid games-tech startup.

sessions.title: Dealing Well With Difficult Feedback
sessions.copy:
Just like anyone who has applied for CODE funding or pitched to a publisher, Balancing Monkey Games has received some tough feedback.

Company Directors Sam and Anna will talk through the process they went through recently in response to publisher critique of their upcoming game.

speakers.copy: Anna and Sam Barham founded Balancing Monkey Games in 2017, and Anna picked up the role of Managing Director in September 2020. Prior to this she managed a medical centre for five years, gained an MSc in Psychology, and has worked in fundraising, volunteer coordination, and tutoring disabled adults.

Anna and Sam Barham founded Balancing Monkey Games in 2017, and Anna picked up the role of Managing Director in September 2020. Prior to this she managed a medical centre for five years, gained an MSc in Psychology, and has worked in fundraising, volunteer coordination, and tutoring disabled adults.

Sam began working on his first game Before We Leave in 2017 as a hobby project, while balancing the other demands of full-time work and fatherhood. He started his software development career 25+ years ago, working on the children’s television programme “Squirt” at Animation Research Limited and other assorted tomfoolery.

sessions.title: Bureaucracy Isn’t a Bug
sessions.subtitle: Why even small studios need big rules
sessions.copy:
In this practical and forward-looking talk, Aryuna Banzarova, Deputy Executive Director at Mytona, explains why clear processes aren’t bureaucracy — they’re a foundation for freedom and creativity.

Drawing on her experience at the intersection of legal, business operations, and strategy, she shows how to integrate compliance into daily workflows without slowing innovation. Aryuna guides the audience through the full product journey — from idea to launch — emphasizing the value of simple actions like signing proper IP contracts, using open-source wisely, and applying lightweight tracking tools. She proves that so-called “legal stuff” actually reduces risk, saves time, and helps teams focus on what matters most: building great products.

With real examples, step-by-step advice, and a strategic lens, Aryuna makes a compelling case: smart processes aren’t about control — they’re about enabling sustainable growth.

With real examples, step-by-step advice, and a strategic lens, Aryuna makes a compelling case: smart processes aren’t about control — they’re about enabling sustainable growth.

speakers.copy:
Aryuna Banzarova is Deputy Executive Director at Mytona Group, where she leads long-term growth strategies, implements internal control systems, and supports sustainable international development. With experience in administration, law and strategy, she excels at solving complex challenges, building processes, and coordinating cross-functional teams.

After moving to Singapore in 2021 to grow professionally in a global environment, Aryuna relocated to New Zealand in 2023, where she continues to contribute to Mytona’s international and regional development.

A committed professional and a mother, Aryuna balances work with raising her daughter — a combination that inspires her people-focused, sustainable approach to management. Outside of work, she enjoys sports as a way to recharge and stay grounded.

sessions.title: ASMR for Goblins
sessions.copy: A deep dive into the sound design of Goblins of Elderstone - a city builder with a Goblin vibe.

speakers.copy:
Bart Klepka is the Creative Video & Audio Lead at Outerdawn Ltd based in Auckland NZ. With a game industry career spanning two decades, he has a passion for marrying audio to creative visuals and interactive systems.

Having covered multiple disciplines within game audio development, Bart enjoys sharing knowledge and retrospectives.

sessions.title: Organising Your Dev Life With Obsidian
sessions.copy:
I take great joy in both talking about Obsidian (a markdown note taking application) to others and improving my systems within it. It's my goal to introduce people to it, give them an idea of some of the different ways it can work and provide a solid starting point for anyone interested in trying it out for themselves. Feedback I've frequently gotten from others who have opened Obsidian, is that they just don't know where to start.

I'll cover: PARA structure and theory and why I modified it, templates for my daily, weekly, monthly, project and meeting notes. Automations I have made for projects and how you too can make them. Plugins I use and alternatives. The differences between my work and personal vaults.

This is very much from the perspective of a software engineer with AuDHD organising themselves.

speakers.copy: Charlie is a queer trans UI engineer currently working for Sledgehammer Games in Australia. They are an AuDHD bean with a keen interest in code, cats and coffee. They'll happily talk for hours about wavefunction collapse, Obsidian or their cat Guinny!

sessions.title: Beyond Graphics:
sessions.subtitle: Environmental Storytelling in 'Into the Dead: Our Darkest Days'
sessions.copy:
This talk explores how the environment art of Into the Dead: Our Darkest Days is shaped by creative vision, technical constraints, and the need for authentic, story-rich spaces. Rather than focusing solely on graphics, it examines the challenges and opportunities presented by the game.

Starting with a reframing of what makes “good” environment art, the presentation highlights the challenges and opportunities of environmental storytelling in worldbuilding, reinforcing gameplay, and engaging players. It then introduces a few practical tips/methods artists can use such as: prop design, object placement, and lighting.
Through behind-the-scenes examples, the speaker shares how subtle storytelling choices—like furniture layout or grime placement—shaped believable, grounded environments. While based on a 2.5D game, the insights are broadly applicable across genres and art styles

speakers.copy:
Chellew (Xiaoyan) Wu is a driven artist dedicated to creating work that tells stories and offers new perspectives.

After completing her studies in New Zealand and the United States, she began her career in the games industry before expanding into various digital fields, including media, VR, and arch-viz. Prior to returning to games at PikPok in early 2024, she spent three years as a 3D modeller at WetaFX.

Chellew believes that while beautiful visuals matter, it’s creativity and storytelling that truly breathe life into art and make it resonate.

sessions.title: Did you Know?
sessions.subtitle: Humans Exist in Game Dev.
sessions.copy:
This talk emphasises the crucial role of human elements in game development, exploring how empathy, vulnerability, authenticity, and fun can transform teams. I use my real life example from a production lens and what I did to get a good team dynamic going using the above.

As a culturally diverse human, I would also bring in my unique perspective of leveraging our common humanity around these elements, backed up by studies and data done in the cooperate world. Rather than solely focusing on hitting targets and producing outcomes, it's all about fostering an environment where everyone enjoys their contributions.

Outcome-> People have their needs met which then translates into productivity within the process of game dev.

This presentation is designed to inspire game developers to cultivate such environments in their own workplaces, underscoring the idea that embracing our human aspects can significantly enhance our professional lives and the games we develop.

speakers.copy:
I am a Third Culture Kid (TCK) — I’ve never really learned to stop experiencing life. I’ve moved moderately through places, careers, and phases of life, often finding myself on the edge of an identity crisis. I try (and try is the important word here) to embody empathy, vulnerability, and authenticity in everything I do.

This journey has come full circle — from coding, to designing VR training games, being a receptionist and not knowing what I wanted to do with my life to realizing that, at my core, I have always wanted to work for and with people. Lifting others up and supporting them brings out my sense of purpose.

So here I am, “production-ing” at PikPok, trying to always putting people first, then products.

sessions.title: Surviving Game Design
sessions.copy:
This is an honest look at the various challenges that I have experienced as a Game Designer and the skills I have developed to overcome struggles while advancing in my career across various games and teams.

The talk is open to all, but the people who will get the most value from it will be Game Designers entering the industry or people wanting to know more about the role of a Game Designer.

Listeners should have a series of key takeaway points and leave with a sense of both inspiration, empathy, and valuable learning.

speakers.copy:
My current role is Senior Game Designer at PikPok, where I’ve been working for over 5 years now. My career has a wide range of examples of creating engaging and user-friendly experiences through thoughtful design, clear documentation, prototyping, and player empathy.

I’m passionate about understanding what motivates players and developers, and I use that insight to craft games that not only deliver on user satisfaction but also meet business goals.

sessions.title: Emotional Climate Change:
sessions.subtitle: The inner landscapes of horror
sessions.copy:
Horror is the most primal genre, grounded in experiences that resonate with deep human fears and emotional landscapes.

This talk explores how effective horror IP development starts with understanding the connection between external terrors and internal emotional states. Using case studies from successful indie horror games, emerging film franchises, and original IP development of the upcoming Tiny Haunted Bookshop, we'll examine how the most effective horror creates a "psychic bridge" between creator and audience.

speakers.copy: Colin is a narrative and strategy specialist who is the creator of the horror worlds Project Tempest and Tiny Haunted Bookshop. Nominated for the Australasian Shadows and International Shirley Jackson awards, Colin is (probably) the only person to write dialogue for car-driving zombies and a sitting Prime Minister in the same year. His working background spans startups, governance, creative development, disaster recovery, and crisis management.

sessions.title: The Campfire in The Storm
sessions.subtitle: Leadership Storytelling during Crisis
sessions.copy:
This talk explores how effective leaders use storytelling as an interactive framework that helps teams navigate through chaos. Drawing on crisis management experience from disaster recovery, high-growth startups and scaleups, and troubled projects across industries, we'll examine how stories shape team resilience, decision-making, and ultimately, the games we create.

Learn practical techniques for guiding your people through chaos. For studio leads, producers, and anyone responsible for guiding teams through difficult circumstances.

speakers.copy: Colin is a narrative and strategy specialist who is the creator of the horror worlds Project Tempest and Tiny Haunted Bookshop. Nominated for the Australasian Shadows and International Shirley Jackson awards, Colin is (probably) the only person to write dialogue for car-driving zombies and a sitting Prime Minister in the same year. His working background spans startups, governance, creative development, disaster recovery, and crisis management.

sessions.title: Empowering Creators
sessions.subtitle: A UGC and Modding Playbook for Studios
sessions.copy:
This talk explores how to design and implement User-Generated Content (UGC) systems, including mod support, that empower creators, not exploit them. Drawing on over 20 years as a modder, educator, and former Product Owner at mod.io (supporting integrations for Baldur’s Gate 3, Homeworld 3, Dying Light 2, and others), I will share practical strategies for building ethical, sustainable, and creator-friendly UGC frameworks.

We will cover the cultural and technical foundations of successful UGC, including best practices for studio support, creator enablement, and long-term community health. Real-world case studies from Roblox, UEFN, Minecraft, and professional middleware like mod.io and Overwolf will illustrate how studios of any size can foster thriving creator ecosystems.

We will also explore how emerging monetisation models help studios support creators professionally while sustaining their games in the long term. This session offers a people-first playbook for any studio building mod support, UGC pipelines, or entering the creator economy.

speakers.copy:
David Thompson is a game designer, producer, and educator with over 20 years of experience across modding, indie, AAA, and platform development. He has shipped eight titles across mobile, console, and VR, with roles at Gameloft, PikPok, Wooga, and Immutable. Most recently, David served as Product Owner at mod.io, leading UGC integrations for games like Baldur’s Gate 3, Homeworld 3, and Dying Light 2.

David is also the Game Director of Tiberian Sun Rising, a long-running total conversion mod for Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars, developed under EA’s modding guidelines. His career bridges community-driven development and professional production, with a focus on UGC systems, modding, creative empowerment, and helping studios unlock the potential of player-driven content.

He is passionate about supporting sustainable, inclusive communities within game development and empowering creators of all kinds.

sessions.title: Beyond Development
sessions.subtitle: Mytona’s Blueprint for Mobile Gaming Success
sessions.copy:
Discover how Mytona evolved from titles like Seeker’s Notes and Cooking Diary into a global mobile gaming leader.

This session provides practical insights into our development philosophies, self-publishing journey, and the tools and team practices that fueled our growth. We'll discuss challenges like market saturation, UA costs, and platform changes, and how we've adapted.

Learn about our initiatives, including adding webshops to scale revenue alongside app stores, global team building, and AI integration. Designed for developers, producers, and business leads aiming to build sustainable, scalable game operations, this talk offers actionable takeaways and an honest look at mobile game success today.

speakers.copy:
Sasha is an experienced leader in the mobile gaming industry with 12+ years track record at Mytona.

Her game industry journey started in 2011 at Sulus Games, a casual video games developer in PC market, and further continued in Mytona as the business pivoted to the mobile games market in 2012. During her tenure, she was taking a variety of functions, including that of a Game Producer and a Business Development Manager.

At her current role of an Executive Director at Mytona, Sasha has been facilitating all business operations by ensuring the administrative processes run smoothly and efficiently, supporting clear communication and streamlined decision-making throughout the team. She has been coordinating key areas like corporate strategy, business administration and public relations initiatives.

sessions.title: Game Dev On the Go
sessions.subtitle: iPad tools for 3D Game Art
sessions.copy:
In 2012 I tried Zbrush for the first time. I was so lost and confused that I gave up 3D and chose a career in 2D art. In 2020, the pandemic had me jobless so I gave it a second go testing an iPad sculpting app. I was hooked and my career in 3D reborn.

Today I've fully embraced 3D and this app is still relevant in my workflow.

My goal for this talk is to showcase the variety of tools iPads offer for 3D production and how they compare to PC counterparts in price, capability and ux. As well as a live demo of how I incorporate them in my pipeline.

speakers.copy:
Érika Casab is a Mexican Game Artist now based in NZ, working for Saltworks Entertainment. With over 10 years of experience in creative fields such as comics, animation, film, video games; she has worked with clients in USA, Latin America, Australia and New Zealand. She is also known for her educational content for Small Robot Studio that has gathered on Youtube more than 4 million views and +75K subscribers.

Outside of work, her passions include snowboarding, horseback riding, dog training and eating spicy chips.

sessions.title: Game Design is Business Design
sessions.subtitle: Learnings from "Warrior Chef"
sessions.copy:
Warrior Chef won Kiwi Game Starter in 2022, but still remains without a release date in sight. This talk takes a brutally honest look at internal and external factors that held our game back from completion, from the perspective of a game designer and business leader.

I'll examine topics like genre, structure, market fit, and perception.

After years of publisher meetings at conferences, design iterations, and industry research, I'm looking to deconstruct the choices game designers make to show what would have made Warrior Chef a more purpose-built and economically viable product in the current indie game market.

This talk primarily helps any developers working on small to mid-sized indie games, while also providing new perspectives and techniques for specialised game designers. Includes references to game design literature, case studies, leading game marketing advice, and my own experiences.

speakers.copy:
Co-founder and Lead Designer of Rare Parrot Games, makers of KGS 1st place winner 'Warrior Chef'. Multiple grant recipient from various NZ organisations; I've travelled to GDC, Gamescom, PAX AUS and GCAP to showcase our game and negotiate with publishers on behalf of the studio.

The past 4 years of experiences and research have honed my game design intuition and industry knowledge, and I'm hoping to share a useful perspective in my talk.

sessions.title: Fair play
sessions.subtitle: Understanding the Fair Trading Act
sessions.copy:
This session, presented by the Commerce Commission, offers game developers a practical introduction to some of their obligations under the Fair Trading Act.

Drawing on recent compliance monitoring and real-world examples, Iain Sutherland and Grant McIntosh discuss five common risks to avoid when you design, promote, and price games in New Zealand.

Take advantage of this valuable opportunity to engage directly with the Commission and to strengthen your compliance practices.

speakers.copy:
Iain Sutherland is a Fair Trading investigator with a focus on online sales practices and digital design. Iain specialises in identifying misleading sales tactics used by global businesses online.

With four years in compliance and investigation roles at the Commerce Commission, and a personal passion for gaming, Iain brings important insight from his work into the way consumer law principles apply to digital game design.

Grant McIntosh is a Principal Compliance Adviser with a background in standards compliance and enforcement. Grant has worked at the Commerce Commission for ten years including stints in fair trading investigations, product safety, and compliance. The Commission’s Engagement and Compliance team undertakes monitoring to identify trends, and engages with businesses to clarify regulatory expectations.

sessions.title: Bending pixels to your will
sessions.subtitle: Shaders for all levels
sessions.copy:
Ian Shephard will be talking all things shaders without code: what they are, how they can be used, and some engine-independent techniques and tricks.

This talk is intended for all levels of experience and will be featuring shader graph usage.

speakers.copy: Ian has more than two decades of experience working as a programmer specializing in technical design and technical art. He has worked with a number of New Zealand based studios like Cloudfire Studios, Little Lost Fox, Dinosaur Polo Club, Synty Studios and has even helped build and launch games for big international brands like Jaguar and Wimbledon.

sessions.title: Crossing the Entry Level Canyon
sessions.copy:
At the end of last year I finished my degree and 2 months later I got my very first job as a game developer. This talk elaborates on my experience job hunting and how I have put myself in a position for success. A

long with an overview of my history I will delve into actionable tips, trick and acknowledgements that there is no one correct way to get into the industry.

speakers.copy:
Having finished my Bachelors of Screen Arts with Honors Majoring game development at the end of last year I jumped into my first industry job in Feb of this year. Geared with honours research about game feel and player interactions I have been the sole game designer and programmer on a 3 person team creating Note Worthy, a music education game designed to bridge the gap between music theory and entertaining narrative lead games.

Over the last 4 years I have heavily engaged with the Wellington games community, going to every networking event I could get my hands on, running Massey very own game developers club and talking as many industry peeps as I can find to gather as much insight as I can about finding entries into this wonderful industry.

I am now very excited to share all of the knowledge I have collated with those just a few step behind me in their career journeys.

sessions.title: Bringing stability to Rival Stars Horse Racing
sessions.copy:
This talk is aimed at Team Leads and Production Staff.

I tell the story of my work with Rival Stars Horse Racing after I was called in to help them recover from a string of live issues. I discuss the principles and changes that led to a return to stability.

speakers.copy:
After studying 3D and graphic designs, I started making games with some friends in South Africa in 2007. I moved to Auckland to work as a Lead Game Designer on Wonder Zoo at Gameloft, before doing the same on Monster Blade at Nubee in Singapore, and then moved to Germany to be the Product Lead on Monster World for Wooga. Missing New Zealand, I came to PikPok as a Product Manager, and worked on a range of games from Adventure Express, to Into the Dead (One and Two), Shadow Wars, Rival Stars Horse Racing, and many more. I became the first Production Manager, over seeing other Product Owners, and led the way in exploring many new development tools.

During this time I became an Enterprise Agile Coach, a Master Transformative Coach, served as President of the New Zealand branch of the International Coaching Federation, I authored a Leadership Development Framework called the  Mind Forge Leadership Behaviour and Team Development Journey by Situational Clarity, and published Positive Epic Fantasy Fiction. (As someone with ADHD, I like to keep busy)

Most of this journey was powered by a love for games and stories, a recognition that I wasn't great at things I valued, like leadership, and a desire to get better at those things, then investing all my focus into improving them.

sessions.title: Video Game Trailers
sessions.subtitle: Capturing Lightning in a Bottle
sessions.copy:
This presentation is all about video game capture for trailers. I will cover the technical setup (that I use at Buddha Jones) as well as the creative process.

We'll go over how we "debug" the game, what we look for when writing our scripts, how we shot list and plan out certain sequences, what sort of debug tools really make a video game look good, and how developers can improve their own marketing by adding things to the game early in production.

speakers.copy: Jason studied film producing at UNC School of the Arts and crewed on several feature films while attending college. After graduation, he moved out to Los Angeles to continue working in the entertainment industry. Over the course of 14 years, he worked in physical production, post production, visual effects, and writing. While trying to find work between shows, a friend of his asked him to work as a capture tech at Buddha Jones. He’s been there for 6 years and now leads their game capture department.

sessions.title: Transforming Climate Data into Experience
sessions.subtitle: Technical Innovation with Human Connection
sessions.copy:
Climate change can feel abstract, data-heavy, and difficult to connect with emotionally. In Our Changing City, we created an immersive climate storytelling experience using Unreal Engine, GIS data, and human-centered design principles. Built on Wellington's 3D Digital City Model, we blended spatial data with mana whenua narratives to help communities see, feel, and understand climate change in their own backyard.

Our technical approach included GIS data integration, procedural terrain transitions, archival layering, state systems, content renders, and physical installation deployment. By bringing together digital innovators, scientists, cultural advisors, and storytellers, we developed a tool that puts people at the heart of the experience.

This project demonstrates how technical excellence can serve community, culture, and connection - and how game technologies can transform public understanding of critical issues like climate change

speakers.copy:
Jeff is a tech lead who bridges the gap between innovation and storytelling. Building immersive digital experiences, he combines technical expertise with a strong creative vision to craft solutions that engage users and push boundaries.

Jeff thrives on complex challenges, transforming ambitious concepts into reality through thoughtful leadership and hands-on development. His cross-platform expertise allows him to create seamless experiences that leverage the unique strengths of each technology.

Known for spotting technological opportunities and solving problems creatively, Jeff brings both analytical thinking and artistic sensibility to every project. He values knowledge sharing and takes pride in mentoring team members, helping them grow while tackling new concepts.

In fast-paced environments, Jeff's blend of technical skill, leadership ability, and creative insight makes him an ideal collaborator for projects that demand both innovation and practical execution.

sessions.title: Creating games with weird game engines
sessions.copy:
"If you’re creating a commercial video game in 2025, you should be using Unity or Unreal. But what if you're not?

In this talk, we will go through some of the pros, cons, risks, workarounds, and things you will need to consider and address -- especially if you are looking to work with a publisher, or run a sustainable business -- from our real-world experience in creating a 2D base-building game.

Audience: new indie developers, studios in pre-production, and publishers/funders.

Topics:

- A brief history of (base building) games and their underlying engines.

- Why are you considering something that isn't industry standard?

- You may have no licensing fees - but at what cost?

- What would you do if you suddenly needed to scale (e.g. release)?

- What are your plans for porting?

- Is there a risk your engine could be abandoned?

- Can you secure a publisher?

- Have you considered your players?

Goal: To develop understanding of the risks & rewards of using an unusual game engine, and to be able to start planning ahead."

speakers.copy:
Jevon Wright (she/her) is a studio founder, software engineer, community volunteer, musician, and aspiring game designer based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Aotearoa. She has been making video games in her spare time since she was 12, and is the solo developer behind the upcoming base-building/simulation game Adaptory.

Jevon holds a PhD in Computer Science and has worked professionally in New Zealand’s web and software industry for over two decades as a software engineer, front-end lead, team lead, and most recently as a Solutions Architect.

sessions.title: It's Dangerous To Go Alone:
sessions.subtitle: Avoiding Legal Pitfalls
sessions.copy: This talk will run through common legal issues that are likely to arise for game studios and how to address these, including business structure, employment, IP management, licensing and general contracting, and getting the best value from your professional advisors.

speakers.copy:
I'm a specialist in intellectual property and commercial law, with a keen interest and background in gaming and other entertainment work.

I work with several early stage gaming studios, as well as acting for several of the largest businesses in the global gaming industry.

sessions.title: Weaving the Net
sessions.subtitle: DREDGE and Yarn Spinner
sessions.copy:
DREDGE, the 2023 eldritch fishing game, met with overwhelming critical acclaim and commercial success, in no small part to its clever delivery of its sinister narrative.

This talk presents a case study in how DREDGE's narrative systems were designed and implemented, making heavy use of the open source narrative toolkit Yarn Spinner.

This talk will provide, and I promise to you that this is not a pun unless you like it in which case it is, a deep dive in how a moderate-scale indie team was able to effectively use open source tooling to create one of the biggest hits of 2023, with a constrained headcount and limited resources.

speakers.copy:
Dr. Jon Manning is the co-founder of Yarn Spinner and of Secret Lab, a pair of independent game development studios that build Yarn Spinner, the narrative tool that powers games like Night in the Woods, Dredge, Venba, and A Short Hike.

Jon is also the co-author of a number of books on Unity, Swift, and machine learning, and holds a PhD about jerks on the internet.

sessions.title: What Publishing a Book Taught Me About Publishing Video Games
sessions.copy:
This talk will help game developers create more engaging, successful, and innovative games by integrating proven strategies from the world of book publishing.

Attendees will be inspired to discover new opportunities for creating and marketing games with a stronger understanding of how games fit into the wider entertainment landscape.

speakers.copy:
Karah Sutton is the Chief Publishing Officer at PikPok and the author of two books with Penguin Random House. With more than a decade of experience in games and entertainment, Karah oversees the Publishing operations at PikPok including marketing, advertising, customer support, community management, licensing, and public relations.

She has had the pleasure of working on more than 20 of PikPok's games since starting with the studio in 2013, including recent successes Into the Dead: Our Darkest Days, Rival Stars Horse Racing, Clusterduck, and mobile classics Super Monsters Ate My Condo (BAFTA nominee), Flick Kick Football, Four Letters, Robot Unicorn Attack 2, and the original Into the Dead.

sessions.title: Creative Trust Across Timezones
sessions.subtitle: Leading Diverse Design Teams in a Global Games Industry
sessions.copy:
It’s easy to talk about building diverse teams, but much harder to make them actually work. Culture clashes, communication breakdowns, and mismatched expectations are common when you’re managing creatives from different backgrounds. Diverse teams sound great on paper until the miscommunication, creative tension, and “Wait, why did they take that feedback so personally?” kicks in.

I’ve managed design teams across Japan and the U.S., but it’s my personal journey growing up between Iran, Malaysia, and now working and living in L.A., that taught me how much cultural context, personality, and creative wiring affect collaboration. Leading design teams at SEGA (with most partners in Japan) and now at Riot Games, managing a multicultural team out of L.A.

This talk is about those unseen frictions: mismatched expectations, clashing work styles, and unspoken norms. I’ll share hard-earned and tribal lessons on how to lead across cultural gaps, build trust in mixed teams, and navigate creative conflict without falling into chaos or groupthink.

speakers.copy:
Kia Abhari is a Visual Design Manager at Riot Games with 12+ years of experience leading creative teams across SEGA and MARVEL. He’s worked closely with multicultural teams in Japan and the U.S., and currently manages a diverse group of designers in Los Angeles.

Born in Iran and raised across Malaysia, and the U.S., Kia brings deep cultural awareness to his leadership style.

sessions.title: Beyond the Game
sessions.subtitle: Crafting Cards that Connect Hearts
sessions.copy: Exploring the journey of the game 'Deeper Questions' and how it transcends traditional gameplay by using storytelling to create emotional bonds.

speakers.copy:
Kiran is community builder & filmmaker and is passionate about connecting people and moving them to see the world differently. His background is in storytelling being a freelancer documentary filmmaker over 10 years, making mini-documentaries for a range of people from monks to musicians, pole dancers to political movements.

Away from documentary, Kiran has opened a creative space 'MoveSpace' to support artists & creatives of all kinds to create & share more of what they love with the world. Kiran in 2023 brought both of his passions together to create Deeper Questions his card game that inspires deeper connection through storytelling.

He's excited about his new passion of game development and after a successful community building campaign leading to a successful Kickstarter, Kiran is excited to share his learnings and learn from others who've walked this path before him!

sessions.title: The Diminishing Effects of Game Enjoyment
sessions.subtitle: A Case Study of PowerWash Simulator
sessions.copy:
Our analysis of naturalistic telemetry and survey data from 5572 players and 123859 sampled events in PowerWash Simulator shows that cumulative campaign progression is associated with lower in-game wellbeing and enjoyment: the more you play the game, the lesser your enjoyment and wellbeing.

With this, we will illustrate how advanced statistical modelling can yield useful insights for game developers, and comment on the complex relationship between gamer enjoyment, wellbeing, and engagement with video games.

speakers.copy:
Kong a Lecturer in Psychology of Social Media at the University of Canterbury. His research uses computational methods to examine the emergence of online culture in social media and video games, and their effects on mental health and wellbeing in users.

In 2025, he was concurrently a Fulbright visiting scholar at the Game User Interaction and Intelligence (GUII) Lab at the University of California, Santa Cruz.

sessions.title: Game Art Pipeline Shift from Maya to Blender
sessions.copy:
This talk explores our studio’s transition to Blender as a full art production tool for our in-house new game, a co-op shooter called Cosmorons.

As Art Director at Blind Squirrel Games, I’ll share how we approached the migration, adapted our workflow, and trained the team. I’ll present a case study showing how Blender was used to model, rig, animate, and export game-ready assets, highlighting both the benefits and challenges we faced during the shift.


This session offers practical insight into making Blender production-ready for game development with Unreal Engine.

speakers.copy: I'm Lluc Romaní Brasó, also known as "LLUC3D." I'm a 3D artist from Barcelona, I came to New Zealand 10 years ago, here I have grown as an artist working for many great projects and companies like Gameloft, Media Design School and Foodstuff.

sessions.title: Teaching players how to learn
sessions.subtitle: The intersection between tutorial design and education.
sessions.copy:
This talk is a breakdown of the collaborative design process used to work on an "edutainment" serious game with our client Sexual Wellbeing Aotearoa. Our goal was to make reproductive health (a somewhat stigmatized subject) into an approachable experience. This is one of a 2 part series of talks about the project, this one focusing on design philosophy and processes.

Games are an inherently participatory medium and thus provide unique avenues for learning. Information is communicated not only through text but through play and self-guided exploration. This talk will touch on how experience with "tutorial design" in conjunction with "gamification" techniques (Octalysis) were used to design gameplay systems with education in mind as the primary goal.

I will also briefly discuss methods I used to build trust with the client; teaching a team of non-gamers a vocabulary for understanding games as a medium and how this later allowed the client to take ownership of the game systems.

speakers.copy:
Game design is my passion. I have been a professional game designer at CerebralFix for over 4 years now, but ever since I was a wee lad I had been creating little games - making paper prototypes before I had ever heard of the term. I love to entertain, those who know me can attest that I've a proclivity for wit and mischief (sending bad memes).

I am a proponent of the concept "games as art." Games can and ought represent more than simply entertainment, they are a unique medium for creative expression by nature of being a participatory experience. I enjoy long walks on the beach, and deep philosophical discussions on the nature of what it means to be creative.

sessions.title: A People-First Approach to Running Effective Meetings
sessions.copy:
Creative meetings are wonderful yet delicate things - they can be exhilarating… but if not run properly, can become exasperating. This introduces and discusses the importance of psychological safety, and how meeting structure, communication style, and a whole lot of empathy can assist with making meetings energizing, efficient, and empowering.

The first section establishes the fragile nature of creative meetings, and establishes how these environments need to be handled with utmost care to maintain their health and energy.

Secondly, several common problems are introduced, for example:

  • What if a few loud voices are dominating the conversation?

  • What if no one feels empowered to share their ideas?

  • What if shy people never find space to speak?

  • What if attendees stop paying attention?

The third section identifies 7 components that address the problems above, and create environments where teams feel empowered to share their ideas, safe to make mistakes, and excited to contribute.

speakers.copy:
Michelle Olson is a Los Angeles based game developer who most recently worked as a Mission Designer at new AAA studio Lightspeed LA. Previously in her career, Michelle worked as the Game Director and Studio Head on the magical photography game Beasts of Maravilla Island, with a focus on fostering strong communication culture and psychological safety.

In addition, she worked as a Game Designer at Meta, and as Lead Designer on Plasticity, a sustainability focused cinematic platformer. Michelle enjoys crafting experiences with strong values and meaningful emotional experiences, and has the most fun when she gets to help empower her teams and collaborators to make magic happen!

Michelle enjoys crafting experiences with strong values and meaningful emotional experiences, and has the most fun when she gets to help empower her teams to make magic happen!"

sessions.title: Emotion Engines
sessions.subtitle: A Framework for Powerful Interactive Storytelling
sessions.copy:
What makes interactive narratives emotionally compelling, and how can we consistently create them?

This talk presents a practical framework derived from my PhD research. I analysed the techniques of over 50 expert narrative designers using blogs, talks, interviews, panels and articles. The study identified two key themes, emotional drivers and player expression, that underpin all interactive storytelling, along with five core categories: high-level conceptualisation, story structure, character design, choice architecture, and dialogue.

I show how all these elements interconnect and offer practical insights from worldwide experts. While this framework started with studying how game narrative techniques could enhance educational storytelling, experienced narrative designers have endorsed its uniqueness and application for all game narrative.

Participants will leave with concrete tools to enhance their narrative design process and create more emotionally resonant player experiences.

speakers.copy:
Miranda Verswijvelen is the narrative game lead at GeoAR, an Auckland-based studio specialising in digital experiences that positively impact the world, fostering education and empowerment with simulations and serious games. She holds a PhD from Auckland University of Technology researching the intersection of game narrative design and interactive learning experiences.

Miranda has more than 20 years experience in designing story-based elearning and serious games for corporate, non-profit and academic environments.

sessions.title: Divinity in the Dirt
sessions.subtitle: An Anthropological Approach to Lore and Narrative Worldbuilding
sessions.copy:
If we look at how real-world cultures and religions form, it’s clear that a community’s physical environment plays a huge role in shaping its social structures, spiritual beliefs and folklore.

This talk encourages Narrative Designers to think about the in-game environments themselves when creating believable and compelling fictional worlds. Leveraging over eight years of experience in Narrative Design, we'll look at examples across anthropology and modern gaming, outlining how terrain, ecology, and material conditions can inform everything from religious practices to mythic structures in your games.

This grounded and immersive approach to lore creation aims to build strong internal cultural logic for emotionally resonant place-based stories in games.

speakers.copy: Nick is a successful narrative designer in the indie and AAA game space. With over 8 years of experience, he’s known for Path of Exile: The Fall of Oriath, Path of Exile: War for the Atlas, OrbusVR, and as the Senior Narrative Designer for Sharkmob London.

sessions.title: From Campfires to Coding:
sessions.subtitle: Tracing the Ancient Origins of Interactive Storytelling
sessions.copy:
This talk suggests a potential evolutionary path for interactive non-linear storytelling – establishing a throughline from mythic and folkloric traditions to modern video games.

We learn about conversational nature of early tribal storytellers and examine the concept of modular narrative building blocks – archetypal plot components that are constantly reshuffled and reused to create experiences that feel both familiar and new. This feeds into an analysis of divination tools like Tarot and the I-Ching as proto-interactive narratives.

The talk concludes by connecting these ancient practices to contemporary narrative design, reframing interactivity as a continuation of an innate human desire for immersive, participatory storytelling.

speakers.copy: Nick is a successful narrative designer in the indie and AAA game space. With over 8 years of experience, he’s known for Path of Exile: The Fall of Oriath, Path of Exile: War for the Atlas, OrbusVR, and as the Senior Narrative Designer for Sharkmob London.

sessions.title: Into the Dead: Our Darkest Trailers
sessions.copy:
From the announcement of "Into the Dead: Our Darkest Days" through to the release of Early Access, we made 7 trailers to promote the game (as well as a bunch of other marketing videos).

Making trailers for a game still in early development presented many interesting challenges, come and see how we overcame them and learn the secrets of our production process.

speakers.copy: I started my career as an animator/layout/previs artist on animated films and tv shows, I switched into games 5 years ago and haven't looked back!

sessions.title: 5 Things I Wish I Knew Before Becoming a Game Producer
sessions.copy:
In this talk, I will share the five lessons I learned throughout my last four years of being a Game Producer, after entering the industry with zero games industry experience.

These insights are drawn from firsthand experience that listeners can implement into their own roles to help navigate their early career. These five lessons will be:

- The importance of the role and what it entails

- Navigating calm in the chaos

- Learning how each member of your team ticks

- Developing trust

- No plan/roadmap is perfect

speakers.copy:
I joined Balancing Monkey Games as a Producer in 2021. With no prior experience in the gaming industry, I had a lot to learn. Over the past four years, I've had the privilege of working on BMG’s second game, 'Beyond These Stars', which is soon to become my first ever released game.

You can usually find me coordinating roadmaps, managing tasks and team morale. While, also serving as the Social Media Manager, where I create & manage our text and visual content for our social platforms.

sessions.title: Presenting Extremism and Game Development Workshop Outcomes
sessions.copy:
The Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet has been funding research in New Zealand on the extremism and terror. There is international evidence of pathways to extremism include game communities.

I will discuss the challenges of moderating game communities and features of games that can lead to players down troubling pathways.  The discussion of the dark patterns are not just about monetizing players but also the effect on players of game design decisions.

This talk will cover the initial research and report on discussions from the workshop on Thursday.

speakers.copy:
Dr Simon McCallum has a PhD in AI and have been teaching Game Development for over 20 years. He has worked commercially as a game developer, co-founded multiple game companies and supported game development in both New Zealand and Norway.

Recently he has been active in the role of AI in society, writing policy for the University, Government and Royal Society. He has been using AI programming assistance for 3 years developing tools both for education and companies, including patented applications of AI in production.

sessions.title: Beyond Vibe coding:
sessions.subtitle: AI as coding partners
sessions.copy:
This talk will be updated from my presentation at Nordic Game in May 2025 on how to move beyond "vibe" coding into "nav" coding.

I will cover the use cases for Vibe coding, Swarm Coding, Claude Code, Codex, etc .., discuss MCP and coordinating multiple AI agents running on various servers.

This will be a session which will be updated until the day of the presentation as the AI tools for developers are constantly evolving. Programmers, designers and production staff can benefit from understanding how to use AIs to help with development.

speakers.copy:
Dr Simon McCallum has a PhD in AI and have been teaching Game Development for over 20 years. He has worked commercially as a game developer, co-founded multiple game companies and supported game development in both New Zealand and Norway.

Recently he has been active in the role of AI in society, writing policy for the University, Government and Royal Society. He has been using AI programming assistance for 3 years developing tools both for education and companies, including patented applications of AI in production.

sessions.title: Why External Development (ExDev) can make sense
sessions.copy:
This talk explores why External Development (ExDev) can make sense for a smaller or mid-size studio, what strategic advantages it can give you, and how to best prepare to engage with the partners you choose to trust with your game.

From the desire to move away from hire-and-fire to the benefit of tapping into skills and/or capacity that you may not have access to, outsourcing (done right) is a way to scale your production sustainably, smoothly manage work overflows, and bring specialized talent onto your project. But as with many things – what you get out of it is a direct measure of how much you put in.

Studios should walk away having understood:

- Why and when outsourcing makes sense in a game production

- What to keep in-house and what to outsource, based on their studio’s strengths

- Actionable takeaways on selecting an ExDev partner

- Pointers for setting up your ExDev project for success

- And for the studios who do outsource work, get the perspective from the other side

speakers.copy:
Steve helps developers and publishers in SEA and ANZ get their games out of the door and to global audiences.

He held multiple roles in gaming across Production, Publishing, Product Management, and Partnerships. He worked on the product side at Unity, and handled mobile publishing at Electronics Arts back in the early app store days.

He relied heavily on external firepower (Dev, Art, QA) when he headed the game production team at a Singapore studio, and before that when he led a small-but-mighty creative outfit that built digital experiences for consumer brands.

Steve is now on the service provider side at TransPerfect Gaming, a full-service game outsourcing company that helps studios large and small with their game projects.

sessions.title: Stolen stories
sessions.subtitle: From Books to Games and Back Again
sessions.copy:
How can games change printed books? KUU, a game in development from Wellington studio Interactive Tragedy, bridges interactive fiction and hybrid book design, using Twine and Ink for novel drafting and scanned pages as game mechanic.

This talk will explore the strange loop of developing an interactive game and a print novel simultaneously, focusing on how stories, player agency, and design constraints can be used across formats.

Building on our first release, Sub-Verge (published by Pantaloon, UK), and its prequel novella, Subtle Mind, this next project deepens the integration of narrative and gameplay.

I’ll share insights from the drafting and development of the KUU game and novel both, including how physical book constraints inform game mechanics, and how branching narratives inspire innovative print layouts.

Attendees will gain practical strategies for hybrid storytelling and ideas for pushing projects beyond traditional formats.

speakers.copy:
Zach Dodson runs a small, sad studio in Wellington called Interactive Tragedy, Limited. Its debut game, Sub-Verge, was relapsed this year, along with Subtle Mind, a companion novella he wrote. He co-founded the Visual Narrative Lab at Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington where he teaches visual, design, and game students storytelling across media.

He is the author of the illuminated novel Bats of the Republic, which has interactive paper elements, and has worked on other television and screen-based projects. A random selection of experiments can be seen at zachdodson.com.

sessions.title: Games for My Future Children
sessions.subtitle: Designing for Fun, Safety and Exploration
sessions.copy:
This talk will be a silly romp through some nostalgic games of the "early World Wide Web" like Neopets and ToonTown Online, as well as games that actual kids play today like Roblox and Minecraft.

From the perspective of an educator, developer and occasional online moderator, let's break down good and bad game design, talk about how young people have fun, and try to answer some big questions: how can we make digital spaces for tamariki that are nurturing, not exploitative? How could we approach design fun games for young people to encourage their best traits? What does it mean when an eleven year old says "unc" or "whaling" or "skibidi"? Let's find out!

speakers.copy:
Zelle describes herself as a huge nerd, an anarchist, and a stuffed animal collector. She studied interactive technology and game development at Massey University and now works with Tūhura Tech, a charity offering Montessori-style tech workshops to young people around the Wellington region.

Outside of work, her biggest passions are ethical game design, vintage fashion, and great food.

sessions.title: Decoding Product Strategy
sessions.subtitle: How Market Research Turns Insights into Impact
sessions.copy:
In this session, we’ll uncover the often-misunderstood process of crafting a successful product strategy. While the value of a well-executed strategy and product-market fit is widely recognised, many struggle to understand how to actually build one.

We’ll demystify the process by diving into how market research provides the critical insights that shape effective product strategies.

By the end of this presentation, you’ll have a clear understanding of how to leverage research to create impactful, data-driven strategies that align with customer needs and drive business success.

speakers.copy: Emma brings over 20 yrs of experience in expertise in research and data-driven strategy. She established the Market Research department at PikPok and now works with an excellent team of mixed-method researchers. Emma is all about using evidence to 'build the right thing' and use testing to 'build the thing right'.

sessions.title: Brainssssss: Zombie Behaviour Tech
sessions.subtitle: from 'Into The Dead: Our Darkest Days'
sessions.copy:
This talk gives a high level overview of the many systems that make up NPC behaviour in PikPok's Into The Dead: Our Darkest Days.

This includes the low level brain (sense and memory), the mid level brain (organization of sensed stimuli), the high level brain (decision-making), converting decisions into physical action, and group behaviours.

speakers.copy: Sarah, a Wellington native, has been programming at PikPok since 2018, and has had the pleasure of spending the last four years working on Into The Dead: Our Darkest Days, specializing in NPC behaviour. Her obsessions include (but are not limited to) Mass Effect and Buffy The Vampire Slayer.

sessions.title: NZGDC Opening and Keynote Speakers
sessions.copy:
Welcome to the NZ Game Developers Conference opening session & keynote address!

This inspiring session kicks off the 2025 Conference with a warm welcome and an overview of the event's themes and objectives.

Join us and our keynote speakers, David Gaider and Liam Esler, as they share the story of Summerfall Studios.

Summerfall Studios has gone through many different incarnations over the years - the only constant has been change, and their determination to do well by everyone they work with.

From a few rogue conversations in 2017 to the release of Stray Gods in 2023 - Grammy and BAFTA nominations - all the way to a failed Kickstarter earlier this year - it has been a wild ride.

Two of Summerfall's founders, David Gaider and Liam Esler, share the triumphs and tears that have made up Summerfall’s journey, along with the insights they’ve gleaned along the way setting the scene for an engaging conference with people at it's heart.

Don't miss this opportunity to start your NZGDC experience energised and excited!

speakers.copy:
Liam Esler is a multi-award-winning game developer specialising in studio management, narrative design and production. With over 16 years experience making games, in addition to his experience as a producer, designer and writer, he has a background in numerous non-traditional roles including conference management, sales, lobbying, and entrepreneurship.

This broad focus led him to co-found Summerfall Studios with David Gaider and Elie Young in 2018, where he works as Managing Director to build and support the next generation of kickass game developers.

Summerfall Studios, based in Melbourne, released its multi-award winning and Grammy/BAFTA nominated first title Stray Gods: The Roleplaying Musical in August of 2023.

Liam is currently Project Director on Malys, Summerfall’s latest game, currently in Early Access.

One of the videogame industry’s most celebrated writers, David is a game design veteran of over 25 years, having started his career in 1999 working on BioWare's Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn as a narrative designer. His later credits include Neverwinter Nights (2002), Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic (2003), and the Dragon Age series where he acted as world designer and Lead Writer.

He left BioWare in 2015 after briefly working on Anthem to become Creative Director at Beamdog, where he developed several prototypes and built a significant internal content team before departing in 2018 to co-found Summerfall Studios, where he is currently Creative Director.

sessions.title: All you need is some glue
sessions.subtitle: DIY event organising
sessions.copy:
This workshop has a capacity limit of 30. Your attendance must be registered via this form: https://forms.gle/Lya5zAC8oTLKdU199

This workshop will focus on creating community building events through case studies & arts and crafts. I'll go over three successful events I've organized both within and outside the game dev community, virtual and physical.

In between case studies, we'll create zines together that will be your personal instruction booklet so when you leave this workshop, you can feel confident in making your next community event happen.

Attendees should bring their preferred note-taking tools such as a notebook and pen, laptop, or tablet; other supplies will be provided.

speakers.copy: Amila Nuhodzic is a project and operations manager with a diverse experience in digital and tabletop game development, creative design, and people experience. Her skills shine in project leadership, improving processes and workflows, documentation, and building community and culture.

sessions.title: How To Build A Third Person Camera System
sessions.copy:
50 Game Camera Mistakes is a seminal GDC if you're interested in game camera behaviour, but there is very little information online about how to actually program a third person camera system that avoids these mistakes.

This talk aims to solve that by covering the system structure, basic api, tooling, and a ton of math that goes into it, all while steering you clear of the unique problems we encountered in Tales Of The Shire.

speakers.copy: Jacob Grossman is a gameplay programmer who has worked at Weta Workshop for the last four years. For Tales of the Shire, his primary contributions were gameplay and narrative cameras, the gridless decoration system, and other gameplay systems. Prior to this he worked as a game development tutor, an artist in a number of roles in the animation industry and as a graphic designer.

sessions.title: Inside Unreal: 5.7 Overview and Roadmap
sessions.copy:
Come along for a whistle stop tour through what's new in Unreal Engine and what's coming down the pipe!

This talk will highlight key feature callouts, as well as some of the motivations driving them, from 5.6, 5.7 and some of the exciting developments we have planned for the future.

speakers.copy:
Chris Murphy is a Principal Technical Artist at Epic Games with game development credits on multiple platforms. Chris has over a decade of experience with Unreal Engine, 9 years at Epic, a Bachelor of Computer Science, and a Bachelor of Multimedia, culminating in a broad skillset across a range of game development disciplines.

Chris’ role in the Developer Relations team at Epic Games is to help Unreal Engine developers build successful projects with Unreal Engine support and advice.

sessions.title: PANEL: Beyond Launch
sessions.subtitle: Driving Long-Term Revenue from Your Released Game
sessions.copy:
Launching your game is only the first milestone. In today’s competitive ANZ gaming market, where discoverability, platform strategy, and retention are make-or-break, what happens after launch often determines long-term success.

This roundtable brings together regional and global experts to share real-world tactics for sustaining and growing revenue post-launch. From LiveOps, DLC, and platform diversification to smart bundling, discounting, and optimizing local payments, join the discussion on what works in 2025 and what doesn’t.

Whether you’re a small indie team or a mid-size studio scaling up, this session is designed to give you actionable insights into building lasting commercial momentum after release.

sessions.title: Leveraging the Gameplay Ability System in Unreal Engine
sessions.copy:
The Gameplay Ability System (GAS) in Unreal Engine is a powerful framework that can be applied to virtually any type of game to build foundational systems and modular components. From story and puzzles to combat, player interactions, quest flow, NPC logic, and physicalized items - the list goes on - nearly every aspect of a game can benefit from GAS.

By leveraging gameplay tags, events, abilities, effects, and cues, the system enables flexible implementations that make it easy to iterate, expand, and enhance the overall gameplay experience.

I want to show how powerful this system really is: how you can use it in your own projects, and how we leveraged it in “Wanderer: The Fragments of Fate”. It gave us tremendous flexibility in developing new levels, gameplay mechanics, interactables, and narrative elements.

speakers.copy:
I’m a Unreal Engine software engineer with a passion for creating immersive, engaging gameplay experiences and developing robust systems that empower both designers and developers.

After graduating from Media Design School, I spent two years at Buildmedia (now The Boundary) before joining Mighty Eyes as a gameplay and systems engineer, eventually stepping into a lead role developing Wanderer: The Fragments of Fate - a VR time-travel adventure puzzle game. I’ve since returned to The Boundary, where I’m currently engineering a new product using Unreal Engine.

Additionally, I’ve worked on an independent project with my university team called ""Mythos Party"", an online mythological brawler, where I was responsible for engineering a significant portion of the game.

sessions.title: Winning The Race: Multithreading & You
sessions.copy:
This talk covers three key multithreading concepts (threadsafety, threadpools, and determinism), with real life C++ code examples from our open world Unreal Engine game.

All examples are general purpose in nature and relevant to all developers. Attendees are informed of Unity/C# constructs that mirror the UE/C++ types that are demonstrated.

speakers.copy: Andrew got his start 16 years ago making serious games in Unity, before switching to Unreal Engine 4 in 2013. Since then he has become an expert in the field in Australia, regularly speaking at UnrealFest and beyond. He balances his time between contract development on interactive projection spaces and work on his own open world UE game.

sessions.title: Unreal Engine: Beyond Chaos
sessions.subtitle: Building a Procedural Real-Time Destruction System
sessions.copy:
In this technical session, Antonio Lattanzio (Lead Engineer at Blind Squirrel Games) breaks down the development of a hybrid destruction system that blends Unreal Engine’s Chaos physics with fully custom real-time solutions. Built for gameplay-responsive environments, this system supports terrain deformation, procedural debris, and dynamic cracking of static meshes, all running in real time without relying on pre-baked assets or rigid simulations.

Through hands-on comparisons with Chaos, Antonio explores what to keep, what to override, and how to integrate both approaches for maximum flexibility and performance. You’ll learn the basic concept of how to inject custom mesh and physics behavior, drive destruction from gameplay logic, and push Unreal beyond its built-in limits.

The talk showcases real in-engine examples of hybrid physics systems in action, including deformable terrain and procedural fragmentation. It offers practical insight for programmers building advanced interaction and destruction-heavy gameplay.

speakers.copy:
Antonio began his passion for video game development as a teenager on the Commodore 64. In 1997, he published his first game, FightNJokes, for MS-DOS.

He later moved to Australia in 2005 to work for N3V Games and KromeStudios, where he contributed to the development of well-known games such as Star Wars: The Clone Wars, Guardians of GA ‘Hole, and Transformers 2. During his career, Antonio was also involved in the reverse engineering of original arcade CPUs and video game boards for a project called ""Game Room"", which was published by Microsoft on Xbox Live.

After this project, Antonio joined Avalanche Studios in Sweden in 2010, where he worked on their open-world engine used in games like the "Just Cause" series.

Antonio later relocated to New Zealand to work with Gameloft on a series of mobile games, including My Little Pony, Littlest Pet Shop, and Country Friends and worked on a core engine which is still used today by some Gameloft studios, named “Casual Core”.

Throughout his career, Antonio has contributed to the development of various games across different platforms and genres, showcasing his passion and dedication for the gaming industry."

sessions.title: From Concept to Screen:
sessions.subtitle: Structuring for Success in Creative Industries
sessions.copy:
It’s important to set up your project or studio for success from the outset. We will explain how to secure your intellectual property rights early on and ensure that you have clear arrangements with your co-developers to avoid future disputes.

You'll learn how a well-defined structure can clarify roles and responsibilities within your team and establish the economic positions and relationships of those involved.

Investors will only look at businesses and projects that are serious and organised. As your business and project grow, a solid structure will make it easier to scale operations, manage resources effectively, and adapt to changes in the market.

We’ll also discuss how to take that next step into film and transform your game into a movie. We’ll discuss the legal landscape of chain of title, financing options and funding, strategies for creative control and credits.

We’re keen to share our insights and help keep creative industries achieving awesome things.

speakers.copy: Kate Cruickshank is a Partner at MinterEllisonRuddWatts, specialising in commercial contracts with a focus on the technology, film, and energy sectors. With over 15 years of experience, she is known for her pragmatic and well-grounded legal advice.

Lauren Archer is a Special Counsel at MinterEllisonRuddWatts, specialising in corporate law. She has a wealth of experience advising technology companies on their structure and helping them secure investor funding, from initial seed rounds to exit strategies.

Additionally, Lauren has extensive experience representing investors and private equity firms in these investments and exit transactions. This dual perspective gives her valuable insights into maximising and protecting the appeal and value of your project.

sessions.title: Let's Talk About Critical Analysis
sessions.copy:
In this talk I will discuss the practice of critical game analysis, and how it will help you become a better game developer, regardless of your discipline. We'll cover a range of formalised skills that you can use to understand what makes a game feel good to play.

We'll be looking at:

  • Defining language we can use for designing games, looking at how we can guide players with affordances, signifiers, mapping, and feedback

  • Using the Elemental Tetrad and having a good understanding of the MDA approach to design

  • Taking a look at design intent vs. player experience and how important it is to understand your player audience and the literacy they are bringing to your game

  • How to use these tools for every discipline

  • Drawing reference from outside of games - touch grass, experience life and art OUTSIDE of games, and how we can bring this knowledge back into the games we create

speakers.copy:
Hi! I'm Nat, an animator and artist who's been working in the games industry locally for the past 8+ years. I'm passionate about how we use games as a medium to tell stories, animation and motion capture, and emergent narratives.
