I have previously worked at Conical, Skills VR, Mighty Eyes, and Media Design School. Currently I am animating at Space Rock Games :~)

sessions.title: Giving Your Players Goosebumps:
sessions.subtitle: The Game Dev's Guide to the Orchestra
sessions.copy:
So you've played the Elder Scrolls. Ori. Halo. Journey. Hollow Knight. Games that featured some of the most breathtaking orchestral music ever created. The kind of music that gave you goosebumps. How can you and your studio get THAT sound for your game, even on an indie budget?

It's actually a lot harder than you think… and without understanding what's involved in producing great orchestral music, many studios get it totally wrong. Their games miss out on everything that makes the orchestra so powerful as a medium.

So how can you avoid the same fate? Come and discover what goes into creating elegantly-crafted orchestral game soundtracks that make players' spirits soar, and learn how the right composers can bring the same quality to YOUR games. No musical background required — this talk is designed to be valuable for developers at all levels!

speakers.copy:
Sai Natarajan is a freelance composer with a special passion for making audiences fall in love with the worlds that storytellers create. Drawing from years of experience working with live symphony orchestras, he strives to create lush, memorable soundtracks that leave listeners with goosebumps. His current game projects include Adaptory and Shyftrs – two upcoming CODE-funded games from NZ developers.

Though passionate about video game music, Sai has done much outside the gaming space. Since 2022, his music has been performed by the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra on several occasions, including two separate mainline concert programs in 2024. Over the years, he has also written music for children's audiobooks, short films, commercials, and even a mini-documentary for Comvita.

In his spare time, Sai jams with his musician friends, dabbles in photography, and plays far too much Rocket League for his own good. He also weirdly enjoys referring to himself in the third person.

sessions.title: New Zealand Plays 2025
sessions.copy:
Playing video games is not an activity enjoyed by a small group of people in New Zealand. In fact, playing games is very much a mainstream entertainment activity, enjoyed by millions of Kiwis across all demographics.

New Zealand Plays will reveal the latest data on who plays video games, why are they playing games, how are they playing games and how video games enable connection across society and generations.

speakers.copy:
Professor Jeff Brand is an internationally recognised and nationally awarded career academic in the discipline of communication and media with expertise in quantitative research methodology, an intellectual interest in policy for the digital economy, and leadership experience in tertiary operations and governance.

New Zealand Plays 2025 is the 8th report Professor Brand has authored, revealing the demographics of who plays games in New Zealand alongside overall attitudes towards games.

Since joining IGEA in 2008, Ron has played an instrumental role in tackling the emerging issues surrounding interactive entertainment, and demonstrating the positive influence of computer and video games in the broader community particularly within the education and health sector.

Ron often appears in the media or fronting government to discuss the power of games to connect, empower, educate and inspire. Issues which he supports passionately include trade and export, funding, child safety, health, diversity and education.

Ron has sat on many working groups, boards and roundtables including an Advisory Committee Member on the ALRC’s Classification Review and holds a seat on the government’s Consultative Working Group on Cyber Safety.

More recently, Ron took the lead in the merger between the GDAA and IGEA in 2020, which saw the two associations coming together, ensuring that there was a single unified voice representing the video games industry in Australia.

sessions.title: AI abuse and misuse
sessions.subtitle: a panel of voice and volume artists discuss abuse and misuse
sessions.copy:
AI, TTS, and Machines learning use voice and volume talent’s IP and biometric data; this panel discusses the abuses and misuses, and collaboration as creative professionals to protect each other better, and tools we can use to ensure clarity.

AI has benefits, and those include high volume, low-cost jobs, or scratch tracks for timing. Where AI becomes detrimental is when it replaces human actors as standard, and the abuse and misuse of talent's IP and biometric data by feeding talent's voices and volume data into AI, without the 4 C’s for the talent. (consent, control, compensation, and clarity)

The panel includes representatives from NAVA, CAVA, AAVA, New Zealand Actors Equity, and the US-based Interactive Union, and includes background on the interactive strike, tools game studios and developers can use to protect actors IP and biometrics, and how to safely and collaboratively use AI.

speakers.copy: Shirley (Ess Jay) is a voice artist with an interest in technology (ask her about space weather and national security tech risks). She makes pleasant sounds you like to yell (or swear) at down the phone, and also dies on command.

sessions.title: Not Just Tourism:
sessions.subtitle: Planning Your Event Strategy
sessions.copy:
The Pandemic notwithstanding, events form a big part of how game developers pitch, market and publicise their games.

This talk will identify the key international events in the game development calendar, what they can be used for and what the basics of planning for them looks like.

speakers.copy: Vee is CODE's resident Industry Development Swamp Witch and will be asking the questions for the fireside.

sessions.title: Lessons from the Pitch:
sessions.subtitle: Evolving Our Approach to AA and AAA Game Proposals
sessions.copy:
Over the past few years, our team at Blind Squirrel Games has pitched several original projects to AA and AAA publishers, each time learning more about what makes a pitch resonate, or miss the mark.

This talk shares how our pitch decks and presentation strategy have evolved through direct experience, highlighting the changes we've made in response to feedback and the patterns we've seen in what gets the most traction. It's a practical, honest look at the iterative process of pitching through real-world examples, aimed at helping other developers refine their own approach.

speakers.copy:
Hey! I’m Brad. I began my career in video production, editing shows like The Block NZ and First Dates, before transitioning into the world of interactive media.

Over six years at the indie studio Conical, I worked across VR, AR, film, and games wearing many hats and gaining a deep appreciation for multidisciplinary collaboration.

For the past two years, I’ve been a Producer at the New Zealand branch of Blind Squirrel Games, working alongside an incredibly talented team on both internal and external projects.

I’ve been closely involved in our internal pitching process, helping shape and refine the decks we’ve taken to publishers—and I’m excited to share some of those insights with the local dev community.

sessions.title: Game Scoring with Orchestra in Aotearoa
sessions.copy:
New Zealand Symphony Orchestra Te Tira Pūoro o Aotearoa (the NZSO) is highly respected for work in the screen sector and has recorded soundtracks for iconic films such as The Hobbit and A Minecraft Movie. However, to date has only undertaken two game scores.

With the recent introduction of the Game Development Sector Rebate - under which scoring falls – through this presentation NZSO aims to bring the orchestra and our sector’s capability in recording to the NZGDA community’s attention.

From projects requiring bespoke ensembles to the full 90-piece orchestra, NZSO provides complete scoring solutions - we can handle everything from project consultation and contracting, to music preparation, booking studios, engineers and operators, conductors and additional talent. There are easy and cost-effective methods for scoring in NZSO’s resident city, Wellington, that will be exponentially advanced by the reopening of the Wellington Town Hall with its all-new recording facility in February 2027 … now is a fantastic time to chat ideas and aspirations in scoring.

During this talk we will break down barriers and challenge misconceptions about working with orchestras, and make sure that if you have a game that you think might benefit from orchestral treatment – you know how straightforward that is to achieve, right here in Aotearoa.

speakers.copy:
Claire returned home to Aotearoa to take on a Senior Manager role with New Zealand Symphony Orchestra Te Tira Pūoro o Aotearoa in 2019, after almost a decade working in the orchestra, festival and music sectors in the United Kingdom.

Recently back in London, Claire is continuing to advocate and promote NZSO’s incredible work - specifically in the recording sphere - and is collaborating with clients all over the world to make ambitions a reality.

sessions.title: From Passion Projects to Player Power
sessions.subtitle: Mods as Community Engines
sessions.copy:
This talk explores how modding communities and UGC creators become the emotional and social lifeblood of a game, long after the official roadmap ends. Drawing on over 20 years of experience in modding, UGC platform integration, and game design, I’ll share how passion projects foster shared ownership, build a sense of belonging, and turn players into ambassadors.

From the enduring Command & Conquer modding scene — where community creativity has sustained the franchise for decades — to modern UGC platforms like Minecraft, UEFN, and Roblox, this talk reveals how mods and UGC aren’t just content — they’re culture. It’s no coincidence that some of the most successful and longest-lasting games in history owe their legacy to empowering creators.

Today, with UGC more relevant than ever, studios are realising that supporting creators isn’t just a community feature — it’s a pillar of retention, engagement, and long-term game health.

speakers.copy:
David Thompson is a game designer, producer, and educator with over 20 years of experience across modding, indie, AAA, and platform development. He has shipped eight titles across mobile, console, and VR, with roles at Gameloft, PikPok, Wooga, and Immutable. Most recently, David served as Product Owner at mod.io, leading UGC integrations for games like Baldur’s Gate 3, Homeworld 3, and Dying Light 2.

David is also the Game Director of Tiberian Sun Rising, a long-running total conversion mod for Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars, developed under EA’s modding guidelines. His career bridges community-driven development and professional production, with a focus on UGC systems, modding, creative empowerment, and helping studios unlock the potential of player-driven content.

He is passionate about supporting sustainable, inclusive communities within game development and empowering creators of all kinds.

sessions.title: Rules and regulations :
sessions.subtitle: Assuring you’ve constructed your game ready for Certification
sessions.copy:
One of the last steps before you release a console game is ensuring that your software passes platform certification. This can be an arduous task that can fundamentally shift the timing and quality of your project.

Many teams make the mistake of leaving certification testing until the end of the production schedule, when it is far too late to adequately address some of the gotchas that occur when dealing with a major console release, resulting in delays and setbacks.

In this session, I will outline the steps, best practices, and suggested timelines for getting your game certified in a timely manner. Understanding and implementing these tips and tricks could save your project a lot of money, and most importantly, keep your players happy!

speakers.copy:
Megan is an experienced Release Manager at Tantalus North, with over 17 years of experience in the video games industry. Her background spans production, product management, release management and quality assurance, and she has worked for companies such as Pandemic, EA, Krome Studios, THQ, Defiant Development. As well as running indie studio, Screwtape Studios for 14 years.

Megan has lead QA teams on Hand of Fate and Hand of Fate 2, and has overseen the production, release or porting of titles such as Damsel, Unpacking, Cities: Skylines Remastered and Age of Empires 2: Definitive Edition for PlayStation 5.

sessions.title: Don’t Feed the Algorithm:
sessions.subtitle: Data Ethics and Security in Immersive Games
sessions.copy:
As XR developers, we’re not just building worlds — we’re collecting biometric, emotional, and environmental data from our players in the process. But where does ethical responsibility begin, and what happens when it’s ignored?

In this talk, Geo AR Games founder Melanie Langlotz and developer Tyrone Mills unpack the hidden risks of immersive technology, share real-world data breaches, and offer practical strategies to help developers protect player privacy without compromising gameplay.

If your game scans a living room, you’re holding a blueprint to someone’s life — let’s talk about building responsibly.

speakers.copy:
Melanie Langlotz is the founder of Geo AR Games, a studio she launched in 2015 with one mission: to make games that don’t just entertain — they do something. From turning parks into digital playgrounds, to designing scavenger hunts that double as climate education, her games sit at the playful intersection of technology, storytelling, and systems change.

With a background in geospatial tech and a strong focus on ethical design, Melanie leads her team in building games for change — experiences made in collaboration with government, educators, and researchers to tackle real-world issues. Now, Geo AR Games is pushing into impact gaming, aiming to influence behaviour, culture, and even policy and legislation through immersive, community-driven design.

When she’s not wrangling XR prototypes or explaining to councils why fun is a legitimate public service, Melanie can be found tending to her ever-expanding menagerie of bugs, birds, and reptiles — many of whom are destined for pixel-perfect stardom in her next game.
Developer at GeoAR games working on a variety of projects from mobile, web and AR.

sessions.title: Is My Game Fun?
sessions.subtitle: Bridging Developer Vision, Player Reality, and Cognitive Science
sessions.copy:
What makes a game fun? Developers design for it, players seek it, but fun remains elusive.

This talk bridges the gap between developer intentions and player realities through cognitive psychology. Learn what fun really means, how it shows up in player behavior, and how to measure it meaningfully.

speakers.copy:
Nidhi is a game user researcher with a PhD in cognitive psychology. With over a decade's experience in research, she entered gaming industry to apply her research skills in making games for "people" through understanding their psychology and motivations.

Nidhi now has over 3 years of experience in gaming industry and love talking about brain mysteries, and differentiating a good game from an amazing game!

sessions.title: Loot and Only Loot
sessions.copy:
All about items in RPGs. Why do we have loot? How does it appear in the world? What makes a compelling item? What sort of items fit different game types and mechanics?

This is intended as similar to the talk I did last year on damage in games (The Damage Done) - only this time it is items, not damage.

speakers.copy:
Carl de Visser is a board and video game designer. He has worked on the Endeavor board games, Path of Exile, Fortnite Creative and is currently working on original IP at Digital Confectioners.

He lives in the tiny town of Cheviot, North Canterbury with his family, 2 dogs, 2 cats and 14 chickens.

sessions.title: Breaking (and Fixing) Unreal
sessions.subtitle: An Engineer’s Guide to Problem-Solving
sessions.copy:
This session is for Engineers and Technical artists who want to build their knowledge of debugging, optimisation and solving complex technical issues in Unreal Engine.

Attendees will come away from the talk with the following:

  • How to identify, validate, and resolve complex technical issues in Unreal Engine.

  • Best practices for using profiling tools and debugging techniques to confirm problem areas.

  • Platform-specific development workflows and best practices (Mobile and High-level Console).

  • Strategies for risk assessment when making changes to a codebase, including engine source modifications.

speakers.copy:
Hayden Simpson is a Studio Director and Senior Unreal Engineer at Prismatic Studios. He has been working as a Software Engineer for the past 10 years, spanning desktop applications development, full-stack web development, and most recently, games development, specialising in Unreal Engine.

Hayden’s responsibilities at Prismatic Studios span operations, leading technical teams, as well as hands-on development of products. His broad background sees him often providing key direction of UI/UX, as well as ensuring consistently high code quality and maintainability.

In a production capacity, Hayden has managed many projects within Prismatic, ensuring they are delivered on time, under budget, and exceeding client expectations. He has spoken around the world at conferences, delivering technical insights in game development.

sessions.title: A port is for life, not just for Christmas
sessions.copy:
Porting is a great way to expand the audience for your game. Publishers do it all the time for developers, but it can be done when self publishing too. It doesn't have to be expensive, but there are things to do that make it easier/cheaper. Do you sim-ship all platforms, do a staggered release, or do a "post-market port"? All viable options, but I'll explain the pros and cons.

I'll also talk about things to look for in a porting company, and how to manage that relationship (this is relevant to folks who are going with a publisher too).

I've got real world examples of managing the porting for Before We Leave, DREDGE, and CONSCRIPT and I'll have feedback from all those developers.

speakers.copy:
Jon has been making games since they were sold on cassette tape, and is horrified that many people attending his talks need to look on Wikipedia to find out what a cassette tape is.

In 2019 he founded GameConsulting.com.au where he works with many screen agencies, investors, developers and publishers helping to bring indie games to market.

sessions.title: Leveling Up Together
sessions.subtitle: How to Lead Where You Are in Video Game Operations
sessions.copy:
Program manager Mia Ginaé Watkins has learned to lead and get things done across multiple teams, even without a leadership title. In this talk, Mia shares her journey and experience with support roles in the video game industry and the power found in leading from the middle.

Through people-first leadership - empathy, communication, and care transform into powerful tools to bridge the gap between teams and stakeholders. Lead with compassion under pressure, and shape culture from behind the scenes to turn operational support into community building. Because when we center people and lead from the heart, we do more than get the job done - we level up together.

speakers.copy:
Mia Ginaé Watkins is an award-winning filmmaker, writer, public speaker, and content creator. She's been in the video game industry for nine years, focusing on operations and program management–currently at Riot Games–and has been recognized as one of She Plays Games’ Top 100 Women in Gaming. Before Riot, she worked at PlayStation, growing from a video editor to a communications project manager. She has moderated and produced panels for the Game Developers Conference, DevCom Developer Conference, San Diego Comic-Con, DreamCon, LA Comic Con, and Music and Gaming Fest.

Previously, she served as the Community Development Director for the Black in Gaming Foundation, producing panels, mixers, and game jams nationally and internationally. On top of all these things, she founded the event consulting business, The Mighty Hostess, and is currently writing an epic fantasy novel.

Zaire is a writer and narrative designer for games. She has worked at Unknown Worlds on Subnautica: Below Zero and at Naughty Dog. She is currently a senior writer at Compulsion Games, which just released South of Midnight.

sessions.title: Desiring to Dare
sessions.subtitle: Developing a Reproductive Game
sessions.copy:
A high-level presentation on the collaboration of two subject-matter-expert teams and our journey of building terminology and trust. This dialogue-style presentation would explore the tension points of producing a serious game and celebrate the beauty of industry cross-pollination and individual growth.

We will touch on the game itself and the importance of surfacing a stigmatised topic in a considerate way with attention to information accuracy versus the requirements of gamification.

speakers.copy:
Ragnar Anderson has been working in sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) since 2008, at organizations in the United States, Finland, and New Zealand. Her research has primarily focused on young people's sexual health, sexuality education, contraceptive experiences, and the relationship between sexual health and wellbeing.

Ragnar earned her master’s degree in public health from Columbia University in 2011, with a focus on sexual and health and the importance of pleasure in sexual health. She is currently working on her PhD at which examines how parents and pre/teens talk to one another about sex, sexuality and relationships. She began as the Senior Research and Policy Advisor at Sexual Wellbeing in February 2024.

Paris Smith is a Game Producer at CerebralFix, a Christchurch-based studio renowned for crafting interactive experiences that fuse storytelling, education, and immersive technology.

With over two years of hands-on production experience, Paris specialises in streamlining workflows, supporting multidisciplinary teams, and translating creative vision into polished, playable games.

Her mahi is grounded in collaboration and clarity, ensuring each project progresses with purpose and cohesion. Paris’s expertise is supported by deep knowledge of the game development pipeline, 3D production, and agile project management.

Passionate about the power of games to elevate community kaupapa, causes, and storytelling, Paris has contributed to a range of “edutainment” projects. She takes pride in being a strong bridge between developers, stakeholders, and partners - keeping communication clear, timelines on track, and innovation alive."

sessions.title: Play the Part:
sessions.subtitle: What LARP Teaches Us About Player-Driven Storytelling
sessions.copy:
Live Action Roleplaying, also known as LARP, is all about the player's story. You don't just engage with the story, you live it - alongside the five, ten, or sixty other people also in the game. So let's take a look at what game devs can learn from LARP's seat-of-your-pants approach to narrative design!

I'm going to run you through how over a decade in LARP has taught me how to craft a few building blocks of emergent storytelling. How do you tell coherent stories when the players will always surprise you? How do you encourage emotional investment without taking away their agency? And - worst of all - how do you course-correct when the players think your carefully plotted masterpiece is a boring slog?

speakers.copy:
Sarah Daymond is a storyteller with a passion for figuring out what makes narratives click. As a Narrative Designer at PikPok, she draws on her background in research and analytics to better understand what resonates with audiences.

She loves exploring how stories take shape through a mix of design and player agency, and she's always up for a good discussion (or debate) about narrative design's role in game development.

sessions.title: How to be a Voice Actor
sessions.subtitle: Nationally and Internationally!
sessions.copy:
Hi there! My name is Vikram Rajan and I am a professional SAG-E voice actor and casting director that works in Animation, Video Games, Anime, ADR/Dubbing and more!

This talk will go into details on how to become a voice actor in the modern day. This includes but not limited to:

  • Where to get started

  • VO Etiquette

  • The Do's and Do Nots

  • The common pitfalls and misconceptions about the industry

  • Where to find potential work both nationally in studio and internationally in the remote sphere

  • Engaging with the community in casual and professional settings and more!

speakers.copy:
Vikram Rajan is an Indian-New Zealand SAG-E professional voice actor of 7 years. He has extensive experience providing work in Animation, Video Games, Commercials, Anime, ADR and Dubbing. He has worked with many studios and people across the world from New Zealand to the UK, USA, Canada, Japan, India, China, Poland and more!

Previous clients include but are not limited to: Epic Games, Ninja Kiwi, NetEase Games, NBA, Netflix, Prime Video and MORE!

Vikram is also the first POC New Zealand Voice Actor in Anime! and is also represented for Voice Acting in the US, UK and Canada - making his way into the big time as a young talent.

Vikram is also an experienced Casting Director for Animation, Film, ADR, Dubbing, Podcasts, Video Games - Both Union and Non-Union. Vikram runs an international casting roster with hundreds of talented voice actors across the globe!

He also has On-Screen and Stage Acting experience, with a Bachelor of Performing and Screen Arts from Unitec.

Vikram is a internationally known multi faceted talent who will invigorate all your projects with life!

Shirley (Ess Jay) is a voice artist with an interest in technology (ask her about space weather and national security tech risks). She makes pleasant sounds you like to yell (or swear) at down the phone, and also dies on command.

sessions.title: Contracts for Studios
sessions.subtitle: Red Flags and Practical Tips
sessions.copy:
Contracts are more than legal documents; they form the bedrock of your relationships with customers, suppliers, and partners. We know that studios can't get a lawyer to review every contract, so what can you do yourself?

We will use our legal and commercial experience to share red flags to watch out for, and practical tips of how to reduce risk and maximise outcomes. Join us for some clear and simple advice for all stages, whether you’re developing your own game or doing contract work for others. Warning: this talk includes useful tips and interesting stories. You might even have fun.

speakers.copy:
I’m a commercial lawyer who helps businesses do good things. Based in Dunedin (and a regular visitor to Wellington), I love technology and game development - especially indies. I'm also chair of Startup Dunedin, helping anyone in Dunedin who wants to start or grow something new.

Outside of work and family, I'm a PC gamer and am trying to work my way through as many NZ-made games as I can.

I’m a commercial lawyer at Avid.legal, helping Kiwi innovators navigate their legal challenges as they grow. I’m new to the game development world, but I’ve worked closely with startups, creatives, and software companies - so I get what it’s like trying to build something great on limited time and budget.

Outside of work, I’m a long-time Sims enthusiast and a big fan of clever world-building - whether it’s in games, books, or the way creative studios craft their brand and story. That same appreciation for creativity drives my approach to legal work: I aim to make contracts feel a little less intimidating and a lot more useful.

sessions.title: Small Weird Crews
sessions.subtitle: Building Game Studios That Scale Without Losing Their Soul
sessions.copy:
Lessons for NZ's growing game dev ecosystem from other regions and industries - how to keep the focus on people while growing business value.

Drawing on conversations with founders from studios in New Zealand, Canada, Finland, and beyond, this talk examines how keeping "human scale" at the center of organisational design leads to both better games and healthier teams, but is not easy.

A realistic yet optimistic talk for founders, team leaders, and anyone interested in building lasting creative firms that honor he tangata.

speakers.copy: Colin is a narrative and strategy specialist who is the creator of the horror worlds Project Tempest and Tiny Haunted Bookshop. Nominated for the Australasian Shadows and International Shirley Jackson awards, Colin is (probably) the only person to write dialogue for car-driving zombies and a sitting Prime Minister in the same year. His working background spans startups, governance, creative development, disaster recovery, and crisis management.

sessions.title: BRUTAL Game Development:
sessions.subtitle: Without an Engine
sessions.copy:
Game engines like Unreal and Unity can force your game’s development in directions you don’t even realise. RocketWerkz will share their practical experiences developing their own game development framework BRUTAL, the benefits of the freedom it provided, and why it might be easier than you think.

After making hit PC games like Icarus in Unreal Engine or Stationeers in Unity the RocketWerkz team learned a lot about the sometimes subtle constraints of game engines.

We’ll share practical examples from these games and how they influenced the design philosophy of the 'difficult-to-use but deliberate' BRUTAL gamedev tools, with a focus on performance, scalability and modding. These tools are now being used on several indie games including the highly-anticipated Kitten Space Agency spaceflight sim, which we will use as a case study.

This talk will go deep into the architecture (Vulkan graphics renderers, C++ to C# interop tools, threading and batching), but also share specific examples of how popular engines can force your development's direction without even realising it, and how to bring the team along with you."

speakers.copy:
"Adventurer, video game developer and flag-waving New Zealander Dean Hall created the wildly successful mod and game DayZ, which won two Golden Joystick Awards and became one of the best selling PC games of 2014.

Dean returned to New Zealand in 2015 to found his own studio RocketWerkz, based on the Auckland waterfront. Dean continued his passion for the survival genre, with sci-fi survival game Icarus reaching #1 worldwide on Steam when it launched in December 2021 and sandbox game Stationeers receiving overwhelmingly positive reviews in Early Access.

RocketWerkz has developed its own high-performance game development framework, BRUTAL, which it is using to develop Kitten Space Agency and several other in-development games.

A former Royal NZ Air Force and NZ Army officer, Dean is an accomplished mountaineer having summited Mount Everest in 2013 and skied to the South Pole in January 2020.

Stephen is Chief Operating Officer at Auckland-based PC games studio RocketWerkz, managing a team of over 65 game developers.

He was also chairperson of the NZ Game Developers Association for 10 years, and has sat on various Government and industry advisory boards to help grow New Zealand's digital exports. He also has a career in tech startups, games marketing for the likes of Xbox and serious games at InGame Limited.

sessions.title: Preserving Judgement & Collaboration
sessions.subtitle: Daily Tools for Leads
sessions.copy:
Why do teams of talented, motivated and intelligent game developers (using the best practices) often run into the same problems, and what can one do about them?

This talk covers dysfunctions and ""common sense killers"" encountered again and again over 16 years of game development as a design and product lead in midsize teams of 8~25 people. It addresses the ""bad things that happen by default unless you do something about it"", and gives tools for how to run a tighter team that uses the maximum of their judgement.

For example:

  • How do I prevent standup turning into a status report?

  • How do I create long-term roadmaps without freaking the team out over commitments or spending weeks creating them?

  • How do I stop disciplines from ganging up against each other, like design vs engineering?

  • How do I avoid falling into JIRA ticket hell?

At the end of this talk, you should walk away with tools for creative leads, executive producers and lead designers for enabling your team to work at the top of their intelligence, and to focus on the things that matter the most.

speakers.copy:
Julian is a new arrival to New Zealand, coming by way of Sanrio Digital, Gameloft, Fifth Journey, Uken Games, Socialpoint and SYBO Games. You may be familiar with titles he's worked on such as Hello Kitty Online, Bingo Pop, Armory & Machine, or most recently, Subway Surfers City.

He originally hails from Hong Kong, and has bounced around the world enough times to end up as far south as one can get without ending up in the Antarctic (or Dunedin!) He landed in Christchurch only this last May, where he's taking some time to try working on small projects for PC and Steam - something he knows absolutely nothing about. Good luck to him; he'll need it!

sessions.title: How Do You Playtest a Story?
sessions.subtitle: Rapid Narrative Prototyping and Playtesting in "Call of the Golden Valley"
sessions.copy:
How do you playtest a story? A case study in how we made a 6+ hour narrative game while testing along the way.

Topics include how we playtested critical story beats early and often, questions we found effective for getting the feedback we wanted, how we balanced storytelling between dialogue and the environment, and developer tools we built to allow rapid iteration of narrative and flow.

speakers.copy:
Madeleine Clute, Founder and Creative Director. Maddy came to games from a software career, working for Google in New York City and Sydney across a wide range of products from Google Maps to data centres in both technical and management roles.

Always having had a strong passion for art and storytelling, she decided to try her hand at game development and hasn’t looked back. O’Saurus Studios is based in Melbourne and their debut title, Call of the Golden Valley will release in October 2025.

sessions.title: Crafting Black Narratives
sessions.copy:
How do you showcase the many dimensions of Black characters while intertwining culture and identity with their world? Whether it's present-day Earth or in a magical realm, our panel of writers and narrative designers will share how they create Black narratives in real and imagined worlds while honouring the culture in creating something new.

Featuring Brittney Morris (Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales), Zaire Lanier (South of Midnight), Jarory de Jesus (Star Wars: Jedi Survivor), and Curtis Baxter (Marvel Comics).

speakers.copy:
Mia Ginaé Watkins is an award-winning filmmaker, writer, public speaker, and content creator. She's been in the video game industry for nine years, focusing on operations and program management–currently at Riot Games–and has been recognized as one of She Plays Games’ Top 100 Women in Gaming. Before Riot, she worked at PlayStation, growing from a video editor to a communications project manager. She has moderated and produced panels for the Game Developers Conference, DevCom Developer Conference, San Diego Comic-Con, DreamCon, LA Comic Con, and Music and Gaming Fest.

Previously, she served as the Community Development Director for the Black in Gaming Foundation, producing panels, mixers, and game jams nationally and internationally. On top of all these things, she founded the event consulting business, The Mighty Hostess, and is currently writing an epic fantasy novel.

A game developer who specializes in narrative design, implementation, and programming. Jarory inspires his colleagues and next generation developers through collaborative projects and teaching game development.

As a developer he’s worked on properties such as Madden, Marvel, and Star Wars as both a Narrative and Technical Designer. He dedicates his spare time to a Hip Hop RPG which he describes as a passion project. He has participated in multiple game jams including global game jam and train jam.

As a developer of color, he seeks to amplify minority voices through inclusive design, unique perspectives in narrative, community service, and activism. Jarory is also a community organizer for Black in Gaming (BiG) and a member of the Latinx in Gaming community as well as President of the board for Global Game Jam. His current studio, Coquito Games, is the culmination of his years of experience and passion for telling stories from under represented voices.

Brittney Morris is an award-winning game writer, with projects such as The Lost Legends of Redwall, Subnautica: Below Zero, Marvel's Spider-Man 2, and Marvel's Wolverine. She's also the bestselling author of SLAY, The Cost of Knowing, Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales - Wings of Fury, and The Jump.

Brittney is an NAACP Image Award nominee, an ALA Black Caucus Youth Literary Award winner, and an Ignite Award Finalist. She has an economics degree from Boston University and spends her spare time reading, playing video games, and not doing enough yoga. She lives in Philadelphia.

sessions.title: Level Up Your IP
sessions.subtitle: A panel on considerations for franchising your successful game through sequels, DLC & diverse mediums
sessions.copy:
You've launched a successful game – now what? This panel dives into the strategic considerations for "leveling up" your IP by exploring its potential for sequels, engaging your audience through impactful DLC, and expanding into diverse mediums like books, films, and merchandise.

Learn how to identify opportunities and make informed decisions to grow your game into a thriving franchise.

speakers.copy:
Robert Walsh is the CEO and a co-founder of Krome Studios, established in 1999.

He has overseen the development and release of numerous game titles across various platforms, including PC, consoles (PlayStation, Xbox, Nintendo), and mobile. Krome Studios is particularly known for the Ty the Tasmanian Tiger series, a popular original IP. Beyond the Ty series, Robert has also steered Krome in its work on numerous licensed titles from major franchises like Spyro the Dragon, Star Wars, Hellboy, and Transformers.

Robert Walsh has also been recognized within the Australian game development community, having received an Outstanding Career Achievement award in the past. He has also been a speaker at numerous industry events.

His career demonstrates a long-standing commitment to the Australian game development scene, navigating the challenges of original IP creation, licensed game development, and the ever-evolving landscape of the games industry. He has been the driving force behind Krome Studios for over two decades.

Mario Wynands is the CEO and co-founder of PikPok, a leading publisher of video games for mobile, desktop, and console based in Aotearoa New Zealand.

Since 1997 he has led the studio in building a successful games portfolio that includes the critically and commercially successful Rival Stars® Horse Racing, Into the Dead® and Into the Dead 2, Super Monsters Ate My Condo™, Shatter® and more, which have been recognized with BAFTA and DICE Award nominations, as well as included on App Store and Google Play best of year lists.

Mario is a graduate of Victoria University in Wellington with degrees in business management and computer science.

sessions.title: Get Into Games:
sessions.subtitle: Inspiring the Next Generation of Creators
sessions.copy:
The games industry in Aotearoa is growing, yet many young people (and their key influencers whānau, teachers, and career advisors) remain unaware of the diverse career pathways available. This talk will explore how Industry can bridge that gap, making careers in games more visible, accessible, and desirable to the next generation of talent.

We’ll discuss:

- The biggest misconceptions about careers in games.

- The role of schools, industry, and parents in shaping future game developers.

- Effective engagement strategies, from school programmes to industry partnerships.

- Success stories from initiatives like Get Into Games Aotearoa and share international models.

With He tangata, he tangata, he tangata as a guiding principle, this session highlights the people behind the games the developers, storytellers, and educators who can inspire the next wave of creative talent in Aotearoa's games industry.

speakers.copy:
Shaun Gear is an education and industry engagement specialist passionate about connecting young people with future-focused career pathways. With a background in education, workforce development, and digital transformation, he has worked extensively with schools, businesses, and organisations to bridge the gap between education and industry.

As a former board member of the New Zealand Game Developers Association (NZGDA), Shaun has been deeply involved in shaping initiatives that support the growth of Aotearoa’s creative tech sector. He has led projects like Get Into Games Aotearoa, helping to demystify careers in games and Esports and technology for students, educators, and whānau.

Shaun is dedicated to fostering industry partnerships that create real opportunities for the next generation of game developers in Aotearoa.

sessions.title: Levelling Up
sessions.subtitle: Industry Insights Two Years into the GDSR
sessions.copy:
This session presents data on the measurable impact seen since the introduction of the NZ Game Development Sector Rebate (GDSR). It highlights how the rebate, alongside an ecosystem approach to industry support — with organisations like the NZGDA, CODE, NZTE, MBIE, NZ On Air, and others working together — is driving studio growth, job creation, and international reach.

Drawing from industry-wide analysis and real-world insights, the talk provides a clear view of sector-wide progress, key trends, and emerging challenges. It will also cover important updates to the GDSR and look ahead to the future opportunities that a coordinated, collaborative ecosystem can unlock for New Zealand’s game development industry.

speakers.copy:
Chantelle Cole is a dedicated leader, championing growth and diversity in the games industry. As Programme Director for the NZ government’s Game Development Sector Rebate at NZ On Air, she brings a wealth of experience and a love for fostering innovation, inclusivity, and international collaboration in game development.

Previously, as CEO of the award-winning indie studio Dinosaur Polo Club, Chantelle guided the studio to international acclaim, cultivating a culture that championed diversity, pay equity, and a sense of fun. Recognised by Apple as a leader for women in games on International Women’s Day and as a finalist for ‘Inspiring Women Leader’ at the NZ International Business Awards, she has been commended for her advocacy and leadership across the industry.

With a commitment to creating supportive, equitable pathways, Chantelle is dedicated to driving sustainable growth and nurturing a thriving development community. Known for her dynamic style, she continues to apply her people-first mindset and business acumen to elevate the sector and open new doors for the next generation of creators. When not immersed in the world of games, you'll find her dabbling in everything from pottery to white water rafting, all while wrangling her two oversized, Flemish Giant rabbits.

Tobi administers the NZGDSR together with Chantelle Cole at NZ On Air. Prior to supporting the NZ Games Industry he worked at Riot Games during 6 of its early years of success and went on to advise organisations in New Zealand on culture and Agile development techniques.

sessions.title: Praise The Claw:
sessions.subtitle: Creating the Music of Crab God
sessions.copy: In this talk, I'll discuss the soundtrack composed for Crab God, which was nominated for for Excellence in Music in the AGDA. We'll go over some of the themes. I'll discuss how the briefing, writing and feedback process worked on this project compared to others. We'll also look at what it takes to create a Crab Choir!

speakers.copy:
James Dean is a composer, sound designer, musician, and all-around audio geek. With over eight years of experience in audio post-production and more than twenty years of playing and writing music, he couldn’t resist the adventure of diving into interactive audio. James has worked on games ranging from low-spec mobile titles to high-end VR, tackling a wide range of technical challenges without ever compromising audio quality.

In 2019, he founded Ākau Audio and has been helping developers make their games sound great ever since. James loves taking on new challenges and genuinely enjoys using technology to discover creative ways of telling compelling stories through sound.

sessions.title: Fixing the Flow
sessions.subtitle: Retention, Representation, and the Leaky Pipeline
sessions.copy:
New Zealand might be crushing it on gender parity, but in the games industry? We've got a problem. It's not a secret, it's a "leaky pipeline" and it's gushing!

Women are acing education and rocking early career roles, even snagging two in five senior spots. But then... poof! They vanish mid-career. Are we just bad at hide-and-seek, or are we truly losing future leaders? The truth is, you can't fix what you don't measure, and this lack of basic data (who's hired, promoted, and leaving)has the potential to sabotage our entire industry.

New Zealand's game industry has the talent and the opportunity to lead differently. By measuring our studios' retention, engagement, representation, and sentiment, we can build more equitable studios and hopefully fix the flow for good.

speakers.copy:
Paris Jagger is a design graduate, self-proclaimed woke feminist, and unashamed data nerd with a passion for turning insights into impact. (and making the industry a better place for the next gen of women in the industry).

Paris was PikPok’s first intern and now works full-time, thriving in a space that champions agency and creativity

sessions.title: Tech Art in Shattered
sessions.subtitle: Visuals for a Mixed Reality Escape Room
sessions.copy: A breakdown of tech art techniques used in Shattered, a mixed reality psychological thriller for Meta Quest. Topics include dynamic lighting (lightmap and probe swapping, custom spotlights, LUTs), room extensions using stencils, shatter effects, shader systems, and a few scrapped prototypes. Each technique is introduced with a brief overview and implementation insights.

speakers.copy: Rohin Knight is a technical artist with 10+ years in games. He’s worked on mobile, AAA, and VR/MR titles, and loves tackling tricky problems, building great tools, and helping teams move faster.

sessions.title: Get Stuck in the Jam
sessions.copy:
Games can be made in a weekend, we’ll prove it! Learn game jam tips & tricks for a range of roles.

Join local or online jams, maybe even organise your own – jamming helps gain experience & confidence, we’ve got the evidence.

speakers.copy: Chris and I are tutors at SIT down in Invercargill and teach across the Screen Arts degree including animation, game design and concept art. We've participated in several jams over the years.
I'm at Tutor at SIT I teach in our animation and game design strands

sessions.title: Making Games Won’t Kill You.
sessions.subtitle: Running a Studio Might.
sessions.copy:
This professional services entourage is joining forces to cut the fluff and provide impactful insights on running a business and avoiding common pitfalls: Legal (Wade, Avid Legal), Financial (Julian, CFO4U), People & Wahine empowerment (Natalie, Powrsuit), Banking (Liv from BNZ), and Insurance (Aya, Partridge Advisory).

The speakers will provide short, practical advice to help keep your business on track.

speakers.copy:
Aya is an insurance broker with Partridge Advisory. She helps tech firms of all shape and size understand their risk and secure the right insurance for their age and stage.

In 2023 Aya and Ed Barker dived headfirst into the games industry to help secure better coverage and pricing for Code grant recipients. She is doing her masters in computer science and loves to play games in her spare time.

I’m a commercial lawyer who helps businesses do good things. Based in Dunedin (and a regular visitor to Wellington), I love technology and game development - especially indies. I'm also chair of Startup Dunedin, helping anyone in Dunedin who wants to start or grow something new.

Outside of work and family, I'm a PC gamer and am trying to work my way through as many NZ-made games as I can.

Nat caught the entrepreneurial bug at university and at 19, embarked on her first venture. Twenty years on, she’s had multiple exits, a fair few failures, and everything in between.

With a knack for tackling complex problems, she helped change the financial habits of nearly 200,000 customers through her last startup, Hatch. Now, she’s closing the gender leadership gap with Powrsuit, a career accelerator for women at every stage.

As BNZ's Head of CreativeTech Business, Olivia works closely with CreativeTech businesses in New Zealand across the likes of gaming, education technologies, design, media, virtual and augmented reality, animation, film, music technologies and more.

Olivia is passionate about innovation in this sector and supports businesses with financing, expertise and industry connections.

A Fellow Chartered Accountant, Julian brings a wealth of financial acumen to the table. Julian is the founder of CFO 4 U which provides Virtual Chief Financial Officer services to startups and high-growth companies.

Julian is the recent recipient of Kotahitanga Award by Angel Association New Zealand. The Kotahitanga Award recognises those people in the angel community who have made an outstanding contribution to the industry. It acknowledges those who have selflessly given personal time and energy for a sustained period and contributed to the professionalism, profile and reputation of angel investment in New Zealand.

sessions.title: Lessons from Developing an Educational Cat Game.
sessions.copy:
Our talk goes over the challenges we faced when developing an educational game about caring for cats. We’ll share the difficulties we ran into beyond the typical development hurdles such as navigating legal concerns, giving ample sensitive content warnings, and compiling expert opinions.

This talk will highlight some decision points we found to be important in building an educational game that tackles sensitive subjects appropriately: The difficulties of communicating the importance of microchipping and desexing, showing the consequences of improper care, and making sure our language is legally accurate.

We aim to show the audience practical insight on navigating sensitive content, managing expert collaborations, and making tough development choices when creating an educational game.

speakers.copy:
Carol is a producer, Māori game developer, and digital cultural adviser with over four years of experience in the game industry. Holding a Bachelor of Creative Technologies, Carol specializes in fostering cultural authenticity while driving creative innovation.

She is dedicated to crafting culturally rich, immersive experiences, ensuring culture is represented authentically in the digital realm, with a special focus with the integration of Te Ao Māori.

Tash is a UX/UI Tech Artist with over three years of experience and a Bachelor of Creative Technologies, specializing in rapid iteration and creative problem-solving with a background in VFX and leadership roles including producer and assistant manager.

Passionate about finding innovative ways to implement striking UI effects, Tash bridges the gap between technical execution and visual storytelling to create memorable digital experiences.

sessions.title: Stick or Twist?
sessions.subtitle: Knowing when, why and how to edit your game's narrative
sessions.copy:
Making changes to your game’s narrative can be a gamble, but the payoff could be well worth the risk.

As a writer, designer and consultant, Laura has led narrative pivots in several games. In this talk she’ll look at when, why and how you can rework your game’s narrative to improve player experience and retention.

She’ll give an overview of analysing data and feedback, knowing whether to simply tweak dialogue or overhaul the whole narrative, and trusting the process when it all feels like too much.

speakers.copy:
Laura is a Scotland-born, Aotearoa-based writer with over 15 years of professional experience writing for games, film, tv, adverts, apps, and more. She has a passion for diversity and equality, and loves creating safe and accessible spaces for people to enjoy.

She is currently the writer for Beyond These Stars with Balancing Monkey Games. Prior to that, she worked for Trailmix Games as Narrative Lead until 2024, has freelanced for companies including Space Ape (now Supercell London), Metacore and Papukaya. Her work in games, film and tv has won awards around the world.

sessions.title: Overlooked Skills for Game Designers
sessions.copy:
Good designers elevate their games. Great designers also elevate their teams. Core skills can only get you so far.

I want to share some useful soft skills, processes, and mindsets that I believe take a game designer from good to great. Things that I've seen have real impact over my career, yet feel overlooked in discussions about how to be a better designer or what value a game designer adds to a team.

I hope this will help students understand more about life as a game designer beyond the core skills they are learning, help game designers better balance their professional development, and help hiring managers know what to look for beyond core skills.

speakers.copy:
Luke has spent 13 years in the Wellington games industry, 11 of those as a game designer. He's shipped a wide variety of games at mainstays like PikPok and small start-ups like 2UP Games.

He is currently passionate about leadership, user research, non-violent communication, vision development, and how we work towards a games industry that shares the spoils more equitably.

sessions.title: Delivering A Great Experience:
sessions.subtitle: A Pre-Pre-Production Rundown
sessions.copy:
The single most important factor in determining the success of a game, according to recent studies, boils down to one thing - having your team aligned around a clear vision. If your entire team understands what they are making, for who, and why, you are more likely to succeed.

This talk is about that: How do you make a game people want to play? How do you define a player experience early to set yourself up for success? With a focus on the disciplines of Market Research, Game Design, Narrative, and Art - and with examples from real games - three veterans share useful tips and practical takeaways to help you start your next game right.

speakers.copy: Rick Stemm is Design Manager and Narrative Director at PikPok, two roles he originated. A writer, designer, transmedia artist, and speaker, Rick takes most pride in his community presence, connecting with fellow game devs, leaders, students, academics, artists, and more, helping to uplift the growing New Zealand games and creative industry. If he doesn't already know you, he would really like to.

Emma brings over 20 yrs of experience in expertise in research and data-driven strategy. She established the Market Research department at PikPok and now works with an excellent team of mixed-method researchers. Emma is all about using evidence to 'build the right thing' and use testing to 'build the thing right'.

I am an award-winning Creative Art Director with over 30 years experience working on a wide range of projects including book publishing, collectibles and both table-top and digital games.

I have worked with world-class game designers, illustrators and artisans from around the globe on high-profile IPs such as Dungeons & Dragons, Star Wars, Lord of the Rings, The Hobbit and more.

sessions.title: Psychology, Game Design, Creativity and the benefits of Roleplay/TTRPG’s
sessions.subtitle: (with caveats!!)
sessions.copy:
This talk presents psychological and game design theories, and then explores how understanding these ideas together through research can help us see where and how tabletop roleplaying games (TTRPG’s) may provide a rather unique opportunity for gaining social, emotional, and cognitive skills.

With a focus on Aotearoa, the talk will also highlight existing research, where more research is needed, and discuss how TTRPG’s set the stage for personal benefits through their open systems, curation of settings, shared narrative, and collaborative social experiences.

speakers.copy:
Shaun Garea is a lecturer of psychology based at Massey University. He is also the lab director at the ‘Gaming Research and Investigation Laboratory’ (GRAIL) where his focus is on tabletop roleplaying games (TTRPG’s) and the potential benefits playing such games may have.

Shaun’s broader research focus is on media psychology and how people interact with/and are affected by participatory media (his prior research in videogames has focused on cooperation, aggression, gambling/loot boxes, and obsessive-compulsive symptomatology).

A storyteller at heart Shaun is also an artist, filmmaker, and composer. His love of storytelling and how narratives influence us, how they help us grow and communicate is a passion; one that he hopes to explore with others who enjoy hearing scary or fantastical tales and/or love pretending to be goblins (at least) once a week.

sessions.title: So You Want to Start a Game Studio?
sessions.subtitle: Here’s What No One Tells You
sessions.copy:
This talk is a straight-up reflection on what I’ve learned from starting a game studio — especially the things I’d do differently if I had to do it all over again. I’ll be digging into the missteps, the false assumptions, and the unexpected challenges that come with building a studio from scratch.

From hiring and finances to culture, clients, and IP development, I’ll share what worked, what didn’t, and the lessons that came the hard way.

It’s aimed at people thinking about starting their own studio or already running one and wanting to avoid the same traps. The goal is to give people the kind of advice I wish I’d had at the start.

speakers.copy:
Zsombor Pirok is the founder and managing director of Space Rock Games, a fully-remote Unreal Engine specialist co-development studio based in New Zealand.

He started the studio in the middle of the pandemic in 2020 with a group of fellow university students, and has since grown it into a team that works with major developers and publishers around the world to tackle complex Unreal Engine challenges, while also developing their own original IP.

Along the way, he’s raised over $2 million NZD in VC funding and navigated the many challenges of building a sustainable studio from the ground up. Zsombor’s passionate about sharing the lessons he’s learned — especially the things he’d do very differently next time.

sessions.title: The Secret Sauce
sessions.subtitle: Building a Thriving Workplace Through Wellbeing
sessions.copy:
"In this vibrant and heartfelt talk, Charlotte Stroebel, Wellness and Administrative Manager at Mytona, shares how wellness is woven into the very fabric of her company’s culture. Drawing from real-life examples — from yoga and Tai Chi to surprise desk gifts and a legendary Christmas weekend — Charlotte illustrates how small, thoughtful initiatives can lead to big results in morale, productivity, and team connection.

She discusses Mytona’s holistic approach to well-being, combining fun, feedback-driven activities with a deep respect for individuality, including quiet spaces and opt-in participation. Backed by high engagement rates and low turnover, Charlotte makes a compelling case for wellness not as a perk, but as a strategic investment in a company’s future.

With humour, warmth, and practical insights, she invites businesses to rethink what it means to create a workplace where people genuinely want to be — not just on Fridays, but every day"

speakers.copy:
Charlotte Stroebel is the Wellness and Administrative Manager at Mytona, recently named a finalist for Best Place to Work NZ. With over 15 years of experience fostering wellness across diverse workplaces — including high-profile roles like Operations Manager at the 2010 FIFA World Cup — Charlotte brings a global perspective and deep passion for employee wellbeing.

Originally from London and now based in New Zealand, Charlotte has lived and worked in South Africa and Australia. Her career has spanned event management, community building, and wellness program design. At Mytona, she leads initiatives that support both mental and physical health, believing that small, thoughtful actions make the biggest difference.

A proud parent of two boys (and self-proclaimed expert in negotiation thanks to them), Charlotte blends humour, empathy, and strategy into everything she does. She looks forward to sharing Mytona’s wellness journey and inspiring others to build more connected, supportive workplaces.

sessions.title: The Development of Blackheart
sessions.subtitle: Chasing Your Dreams & Tempering Them With Reality
sessions.copy:
This talk follows the five-year journey of Blackheart; from a novel written by Josiah to a fully funded and launched game on Steam. It covers topics such as securing game funding, navigating publisher negotiations, starting an indie studio, and overcoming the many challenges faced along the way.

With a candid and deeply personal lens, Josiah sheds light on the intense highs and crushing lows of making your dream game a reality. It aims to inspire fellow developers to take bold risks, while giving them a realistic look at the road ahead.

speakers.copy:
I'm the founder of Hyporeal, a Dunedin games studio who recently launched our debut; an action RPG entitled "Blackheart".

I have previously worked as a programmer at Runaway Play, a designer/programmer at Nutri-Blocks, and more recently as a designer/programmer at Spellcaster.

I am a natural communicator and multi-disciplinary creative who boasts not only strong programming skills, but a track record of leading teams and shipping quality games that resonate with players.

sessions.title: The Art of Saying No
sessions.subtitle: Client Management Edition
sessions.copy:
From a recovering "people pleaser" this session will equip you with practical techniques for setting expectations, advocating for your team, and keeping projects (and relationships) healthy.

I’ll share the strategies I’ve developed to manage expectations, set boundaries, and keep projects on track without burning bridges or burning out the team. These tips come from my experience as a producer and my various side quests in life.

speakers.copy:
I'm Kasey, a line producer at 37Degrees Studio. Over the past 9 years, I've worked in film, TV, games and location based experiences. Spending most of my time in visual effects, a bit in linear content for games and now I spend most my time supporting my creative development team, anything from concept art to full 3D enviornments.

I love the variety of projects I get to be involved with and the different industries and people who are involved. In my spare time, I am a pilot, a mum and a serial hobby-starter.

sessions.title: Beyond the Numbers
sessions.subtitle: How Data Empowers Creative Game Development
sessions.copy:
Game development can be seen by some as a battle between creative vision and hard metrics - but what if data didn’t limit creativity, and instead fuelled it?

In this talk, we’ll explore how data analysis can become a powerful ally for creative teams, helping shape more engaging, player-centric experiences. Drawing from real-world examples, we’ll dive into how player behavioral insights can guide decisions, empower creativity, and inspire new ideas.

Whether you’re a designer, producer, or analyst, you’ll walk away with practical strategies to build a data-informed development culture - one where creativity and analysis don’t just coexist, but thrive together.

speakers.copy: Laura leads the analytics department at PikPok, providing our development teams and decision makers with insights derived from more than 1 billion user-generated data points daily. Inspired by a youth spent crafting custom games and communities in Warcraft 3, and over a decade of professional experience in analytics, Laura's a passionate advocate for the intersection between data and creativity.

sessions.title: Nintendo's Design Philosophy
sessions.copy:
I have had the privilege of interviewing several Nintendo game developers over the years on my Youtube Podcast called Kiwi Talkz, so I would like to provide some context to the 'Nintendo' philosophy of how they design games.

Nintendo seldom lays developers off and closes studios. Their design philosophy and the treatment of their employees are intertwined. They have a 98% retention rate and continue to push the envelope at the same time. With the AAA industry imploding in real time, as the cost of game development skyrockets it's important that we look to the oldest game developer Nintendo to ensure NZ game devs have the wisdom to navigate these pitfalls.

During the talk, I will provide clips from many interviews I have done, to provide greater context. Some clips from my interviews to further emphasize my points.

https://youtu.be/tf0sveSLY10

https://youtu.be/RUMDE3BB_b8

speakers.copy:
My name is Reece Reilly and I am a video game developer interviewer who hosts a podcast called Kiwi Talkz where I speak with various game developers about their field of expertise and games they have worked on. The main objective with doing these interviews is to humanise game devs, so gamers can learn to appreciate the sacrifices they make to bring gamers joy.

I have spoken with over 100+ game devs from companies such as Valve, Nintendo, Rockstar, Bethesda and more. The guests range anywhere from composers such as Mick Gordon (composer on DOOM 2016/Eternal) to Shawn Layden (Former Chairman Of Playstation & CEO of Sony Interactive.)

sessions.title: Taking your game to the next level
sessions.subtitle: Demystifying the legal issues
sessions.copy: A talk taking attendees through the legal issues often faced when setting up a business and during game development, including structuring your business to grow and protect IP, raising capital, understanding intellectual property and copyright, and registering trade marks and patents. This year we will aim to focus more on the IP and company structuring aspects.

speakers.copy:
Calvin is a Senior Associate at Hudson Gavin Martin, New Zealand’s leading technology law firm. Calvin helps clients with corporate structuring, shareholder issues, capital raising and M&A.

Calvin has worked with businesses across various industry sectors (both customers and vendors), including indie game studios, and global gaming, social media and entertainment businesses.

sessions.title: From Wild Guesses to Winning Games
sessions.subtitle: The Power of Data-Informed Insights
sessions.copy:
The gaming industry is crowded, competitive, and more expensive than ever. In this high-stakes environment, guesswork won’t cut it. That’s where Market Research, Games User Research, and Analytics (a.k.a. ‘Insights’) come in.

In this presentation and panel, we’ll show you how data-informed insights help de-risk game development and sharpen strategic focus - from concept testing to play-testing to soft launches that measure the right things.

We are the game developers who are skilled in the language of questions, problem solving and critical thinking. If you're interested in understanding how data and insights can add value across the development cycle this is the presentation and panel for you.

speakers.copy: Emma brings over 20 yrs of experience in expertise in research and data-driven strategy. She established the Market Research department at PikPok and now works with an excellent team of mixed-method researchers. Emma is all about using evidence to 'build the right thing' and use testing to 'build the thing right'.

Laura leads the analytics department at PikPok, providing our development teams and decision makers with insights derived from more than 1 billion user-generated data points daily. Inspired by a youth spent crafting custom games and communities in Warcraft 3, and over a decade of professional experience in analytics, Laura's a passionate advocate for the intersection between data and creativity.

Ben has a PhD in Human Factors Psychology and over two decades of research experience. He has helped ship 90+ games, plus worked on 36 seasons of Fortnite Battle Royale.

Previously he was Director of User Experience Research at Epic Games, but has recently returned home to New Zealand.

sessions.title: Charting the Course of 'Starship Home':
sessions.subtitle: Designing Mixed Reality's First Narrative Adventure
sessions.copy:
This talk explores the design intentions behind the DICE award-winning game "Starship Home" and how we used Mixed Reality to not only build a full narrative game, but to inherently involve the player and their space in it. Starship Home acknowledges the player and their space and is trying to expand it. We use the personal space provided by MR as a canvas for a feature length narrative experience.

The talk will dive deep into our four design pillars that helped sell and maintain the shared illusion:

- Making the player active participant in designing the shared space

- Creating a logically consistent virtual space without smoke and mirrors

- Aligning visual fidelity of the virtual and real world by lowering the “real”

- Designing in-game elements with the same physical affordances as real world objects

speakers.copy:
Mark is a leading developer in the XR industry with over 10 years VR, AR, MR & NUI development experience as well as 15 years of experience in software development. He is the director of engineering at Creature, working on "Starship Home", a mixed reality game transforming your living room into the bridge of a starship. Mark was the lead VR developer of the Quest version of "SUPERHOT VR". He is also working on the upcoming mixed reality title "Laser Dance".

Based in Canberra, Mark has extensive experience working with remote teams. In addition to him leading other teams, he is an independent XR developer and has released or worked on several critically acclaimed titles such as Gravity Lab, Nighttime Terror, Low-Fi, Technolust and Aussie Sports VR in cooperation with the Australian government. Industry veteran John Carmack called Nighttime Terror "competently done and well executed". Mark has won a DICE award for his work on "Starship Home", a Proto Award of the Virtual Reality Foundation for his game "Nighttime Terror" and was nominated for his game "Gravity Lab".

Mark is an alumni of the German National Academic Foundation. He holds a Bachelors Degree in Computing and Human Computer Interaction from the Dresden University of Applied Sciences as well as a Graduate Diploma of Computing from the Australian National University.

sessions.title: Playtesting with Purpose
sessions.copy:
With tighter funding, tougher competition, and rising expectations from both players and publishers, developers are under more pressure than ever to prove their game’s value early. Whether you’re applying for funding or heading toward self-publishing, making sense of feedback — and acting on it meaningfully — has become a vital part of the process.

  • Why generic feedback often slows progress more than it helps

  • How to align your pitch, core loop, and audience expectations before launch

  • When (and how) to test to avoid costly missteps down the track

This session shares practical frameworks and lessons drawn from real studio challenges — via a panel – and explores how better-timed, better-framed play-testing can help studios of all sizes test with clarity and purpose.

Our intention is to deliver a presentation within the first half of the session, supported by a industry panel with audience Q&A.

speakers.copy: I've been working in the gaming space for about 4+ years - within a small studio called Mīharo - delivering both serious games on behalf of clients and our own VR title - Colorway Antics. Playful is an exciting new venture designed to support the indie scene through the challenges of publishing their title(s). We are a small core team, offering a range of services designed to provide high-value and targeted play-testing.

Nick Jennings is helping bring Playful, a new initiative dedicated to transforming how indie developers playtest games.

With a background in digital production and years of experience delivering creative and technical projects, Nick now focuses on embedding structured, audience-led feedback earlier in the game development lifecycle.

Antony is CODE's Regional Content Manager, Upper North Island. He brings a plethora of tech skills and experience working across a variety of platforms, such as PlayStation, Xbox, PC, and Nintendo Switch. Testing everything from mobile to AAA. Outside of work, Antony is a dedicated artist who has self-published a number of comic books. He’s also a keen musician who plays bass guitar in multiple bands in Auckland.

Olivier brings a sharp, player-first mindset to every stage of game development. He’s currently leading Dream Team Supreme, a co-op roguelike where scientists pilot giant robots against a monster invasion.

At PikPok, he managed a 30-person team to ship Agent Intercept on time and under budget for Apple Arcade, and helped grow Rival Stars Horse Racing revenue by 66% through player-driven updates. With 300+ titles shipped in 40+ languages at Keywords, Olivier blends global insight with deep QA expertise—having built test pipelines, mentored teams, and embedded quality into the dev process from day one.

Louis Lambert is QA Lead at Blind Squirrel Games, bringing a sharp technical edge and deep experience in testing complex, live games. Prior to this, he spent four years at RocketWerkz, where he led QA across multiple projects and expansions — most notably managing over 189 weekly patches for Icarus post-launch.

His work spanned performance validation, multiplayer stability, platform compliance, and player experience, establishing QA as a critical partner in the dev cycle. Louis thrives in fast-moving, iterative environments and is passionate about embedding QA earlier in development to reduce risk, improve collaboration, and ship with confidence.

sessions.title: Astronaut Diaries
sessions.subtitle: The Long and Winding Road to Success
sessions.copy:
Astronaut Diaries is an Auckland-based indie studio who have done it real in a way that many junior developers don't really appreciate.

This is a fireside chat with Shrikkanth, Tamihana and Scott from Ninja Kiwi who have taken them on as a publisher. It's all about the journey, lessons and long time in development for their debut game, Denari, but also the developers' journey along the way from self-funding and working away in Auckland, to Gamescom, BitSummit and a few PAX AUS's.

speakers.copy: Vee is CODE's resident Industry Development Swamp Witch and will be asking the questions for the fireside.

With over 30 years in the games industry, including leadership positions at Electronic Arts and Activision, and 15 years helping lead Ninja Kiwi, Scott focuses that history and experience on what he sees as the core essentials of sustainable game development: inspired, healthy, and collaborative teams, creative and technical excellence fuelling innovative gameplay, and fair business practices that enable fresh, hungry teams to succeed.
Director of Astronaut Diaries, an indie game studio based in Auckland that specialises in story driven action games. They are currently working on their debut title, Denari.

Tamihana Greaves has worked in the New Zealand games industry for the last 15 years. He first began as a 2D Artist and Animator at Ninja Kiwi, working predominantly on the Bloons TD series. Now he works as Art Director on the yet-to-be released project Denari, at Astronaut Diaries.

sessions.title: NZGDC Closing
sessions.copy:
Join us for the NZGDC Closing Session!

This special event marks the end of an inspiring conference, offering a chance to reflect on the insights and connections made over the past few days. We’ll wrap up with some final thoughts, highlights, and a look ahead to the future of game development.

Don’t miss this opportunity to celebrate the achievements of the event and leave inspired for what’s next!

sessions.title: Minds in Motion
sessions.subtitle: Tracking human experience in immersive virtual environments
sessions.copy:
Multisensory virtual reality combined with motion simulation provides unique opportunities to understand the human mind. We can use VR to simulate real-world experiences under controlled laboratory conditions, and we can track how people might respond to impossible worlds. The breadth of human experience includes subjective feelings, physiological responses, sensory interpretations, and actions.

Emerging technologies make it possible to track all of these factors in real time, yielding rich data that can be used to predict and explain human experience.

In this talk, we’ll describe a collaboration between the Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience Lab at Victoria University of Wellington and Ed Davis Indie VR & Motion-Sim developer, in which we capture the many dimensions of human experience in virtual worlds. Our finding will interest developers who are keen to better understand their users, and scientists who are curious about the human mind."

speakers.copy: Ed Davis: Indie video / performance artist since the 90s - VR film/game Dev since 2018 - recently using game engines and motion-simulators in sync with FPV drone shots and CG / 3DGS tech to create natural / virtual experiences / environments for psych research and immersive gaming
